He said that the officers should explore the possibilities for the same.

In the video conferencing, Principal Secretary to Chief Minister, Rajesh Khullar, Additional Principal Secretary to Chief Minister, V. Umashankar, Additional Chief Secretary of Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare Department, Sanjeev Kaushal and Director General, Vijay Dahiya were also present.

Title: Punjab tally 298; State sees 11 new +ve cases
Article: Punjab’s tally on Friday inched close to 300. With 11 new cases from Patiala, Mansa, Jalandhar, Amritsar and Ludhiana, the state’s tally now stood at 298 with 17 reported deaths. Continuing to add more and more patients to the state’s total number, Rajpura town in Patiala district has reported six more positive cases. All the six cases are contacts of the already diagnosed cases. With 36 corona-positive cases alone, Rajpura is the new hotspot in the State. Followed by Mohali and Jalandhar with 63 cases each, the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder’s home district Patiala now has a total of 55 cases. The district authorities have been blaming a spike in cases in the area on hookah parties that was held there in defiance of curfew orders. Alarmed, the district authorities have decided to screen the entire population of Rajpura town for any symptoms of coronavirus. Patiala Civil Surgeon Dr Harish Malhotra said that health teams operating in Rajpura had collected 58 samples on Thursday out of which six have been found to be positive.The Civil Surgeon said that the health teams are tracing the contacts of all persons tested positive.

Title: UT Admn to appoint authorised Covid volunteers
Article:
The Chandigarh Administration will rope in city denizens as “authorized Covid volunteers” (ACV) to ensure compliance to curfew restrictions and social distancing protocol in the city to stem the spread of Coronavirus.

The Administration on Friday released a standard operating procedure to appoint ACVs, who would undergo mandatory screening and registration to work along with UT Police and local authorities.

The decision to appoint the ACVs have been taken following the directions of Punjab Governor and UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore, who had asked the Administration to involve representatives and volunteers for effectively maintaining sealing of various colonies and areas and for enforcing social distancing and other protocols in the city.

The SOP issued by Administration stated, “Every registered volunteer shall be referred as authorized Covid volunteer (ACV). Every ACV must get himself screened by the team of UT Health Department.”

“The individual volunteers, NGOs, RWAs, volunteer organizations and other associations willing to work as authorized Covid volunteers to aid local police and Administration in enforcement of the guidelines of UT Administration and motivating the citizen to comply the same shall register themselves with the concerned SDM by means of an application at the email IDs of SDM central, south and east,” as per the SOP.

“These ACV will only assist the police and administration. They will not be allowed to perform any official duty. None of these registered ACV will be allowed to seal main road (entry/exit points) by barricades etc at their own level. These ACVs will only work under the supervision of local police and administration and strictly as per the approved plan and duty chart,” the SOP stated.

In case, the conduct of any ACV is found improper, the same will be removed immediately. The work done by these ACV will be treated as only voluntary for all means and purposes, it added.

The SOP order further stated, “List of individual volunteers, if found suitable will be compiled by the office of SDM concerned for ready deployment, in case of any need. The NGO, RWAs, volunteer organizations or other associations should prepare a plan and duty chart for their societies, RWAs and submit the same with application of concerned SDM.”

SDM concerned shall take the views of the local Police and SDPO concerned to decide on these applications. If any changes are made by the SDM in the proposed plan, the same shall be abided by the applicants, it added.

Notably, a curfew was imposed in Chandigarh on March 24 to contain the spread of Coronavirus in the city.

Title: Registration begins for return of migrants
Article:
Registration of migrant workers, who want to return to Odisha after the COVID-19 lockdown, began on Friday. The State Government Registration portal– covid19.odisha.gov.in became operational in this regard.

Anyone who wants to return to the State after lockdown via any means whether air, train or road is required to register by filling up the form, an official statement said.

“The registration portal is for everyone, who wants to come back to the State after lockdown. It is compulsory for everyone to register on this portal,” said Law Minister Pratap Jena.

Panchayati Raj Secretary DK Singh said, “The Odisha Government is expecting that nearly 5 lakh people are likely to return to the State from other States after the lockdown is lifted, said an official. “Without registration on the Government portal, no person will be allowed to return to the State.”

With the registration, the Government can know about their details so that it can make necessary arrangements at respective gram panchayat (GP) level, added Singh.

He said the registration can be done by the person concerned or anyone else would do it on behalf of the person or a relative of the person can fill a form and submit it to the official concerned at the GP level, who would do the registration.

The returnees would be mandatorily quarantined for 14 days. They can’t go to home directly. Sarpanchs will play a decisive role in this. Around 7,000 temporary medical camps have been set up at GPs, he said.

Title: Saving lives my priority: Capt on lifting curfew
Article:
In the past 40 days, Punjab had witnessed three peaks in the Covid curve, noted the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Friday adding that it may not be possible to lift the lockdown completely for some more time.

“The State will examine the recommendations of the Expert Committee and the prevailing ground situation,” said the Chief Minister while adding that the report by the Expert Committee is expected to be submitted by Saturday.

Capt Amarinder said: “In Punjab, of the 22 districts, five are currently in ‘green zone’. The Prime Minister is also scheduled to consult with the Chief Ministers of all States on the issue of lifting the lockdown through a video conference on Monday.”

“I would go by the advice of the Expert Committee, set up to formulate Punjab’s lockdown exit strategy in the matter of opening up the state,” said the Chief Minister during a webinar with leading industrialists, economic experts and diplomats or ambassadors of various countries.

The Chief Minister said that any decision on lifting the lockdown or curfew would be taken basis the recommendations of 20-member Expert Committee, which is expected to submit its report on Saturday.

Reiterating that his priority was saving the lives of Punjabis, the Chief Minister said: “The life of my Punjabis is more important…Factories can be restarted but we can’t get people back.”

If the Expert Committee, which includes medical experts and doctors, recommends opening up, either partially or completely, we will do so, he said, in response to questions.

“I will go by their advice,” he declared, but made it clear that the health of the people was the priority, even though the State Government was aware that the lockdown could not be kept in place indefinitely.

The Chief Minister, during the webinar, extended his condolences to the Italian ambassador, Vincenzo de Luca, for the large number of lives lost in their country due to Covid pandemic. The envoy, on his part, expressed solidarity with the people of Punjab in their fight against the coronavirus.

CAPT DIRECTS INDUSTRIES DEPTT, DCs TO GIVE APPROVAL, CURFEW PASSES FOR REOPENING TO ELIGIBLE INDUSTRY WITHIN 12 HOURS

Assuring the industry of his government’s full support in these difficult times, Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Friday directed the Department of Industries and District Industries Centres functioning under the Deputy Commissioners to provide all industrial units eligible to reopen with requisite approvals, along with required curfew passes, within 12 hours of applying.

Capt Amarinder also assured them that he would raise the issue of Central support for industry with Prime Minister Narendra Modi during the video conferencing convened by the latter with all chief ministers on Monday.

At a webinar, participated by nearly 100 industry stalwarts, foreign ambassadors or diplomats and others, the Chief Minister said that he had already requested the Central Government to find innovative solutions to support industry in this difficult time so that they could continue to pay labourers and workers. The industry cannot pay wages endlessly, he said, responding to the concern expressed by the participants on this issue.

Capt Amarinder lamented that Punjab was not getting its share from the Centre, which had also rejected its request for allowing liquor sales, leading to losses to the tune of Rs 6200 crore in revenue. “The Centre has to compensate,” he stressed.

The Chief Minister also conveyed to the industry the Central Government’s clarification that there would no penal action against any industrial unit if a worker is found infected with Covid.

He also assured the industry that there was neither any intention nor direction on the part of Punjab Government to impose any criminal liabilities on the industry and their CEOs for Covid-positive cases in their workforce. However, he urged them to follow all health and medical safety protocols laid down for checking spread of the coronavirus.

Terming the industry an integral part of Punjab's fight against Covid crisis, the Chief Minister has directed all departments to support and facilitate permitted industries to reopen and commence operations, said an official spokesperson.

Pointing out that industry could function as per guidelines if they provide food and shelter to workers, as per the Centre’s locked-in permission to operate, he also made it clear that all orders giving approval to industrial unit to operate must be sent to the labour, police and other concerned departments so that there is no harassment of industry.

Capt Amarinder urged the industry to immediately bring to the notice of the concerned DC or the Industry Minister and senior officers of the department any difficulty faced by them. If due to any supply chain problems, any industrial unit cannot continue to function, they will be permitted to shut down operations even as the Government will make all efforts to prevent such problems, he assured.

Title: Capt urges DM to allow retired defence personnel to travel home
Article:
Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Friday urged Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh to grant special permission to defence personnel who have retired from service to return to their home States amid the countrywide lockdown due to coronavirus.

In a letter to the defence minister, Capt Amarinder said that in case it is not feasible to enable their return home immediately, then the Command Headquarters across the country should be directed to take special care of them until these defence personnel are able to get the requisite permissions. He pointed out that Punjab contributes significantly to the strength of the armed forces who are engaged in defending the nation, an official statement said here.

He said, adding that a large number of them, hailing from Punjab, are unable to come back to the state at present in view of the lockdown, and continue to be stationed in their last place of posting."Undoubtedly they are facing considerable mental trauma because of the inability to be reunited with their near and dear ones," said the Chief Minister.

Title: Paddy, cash crops damaged in W Odisha
Article:
The entire Hirakud Command Area witnessed a virulent loss due to wind, rain and hailstones since April 21. Farmers are narrating their stories with tearful eyes in view of their crops lying damaged.

“Just a week or so was left for cutting paddy. This year there was a bumper crop. But see the paddy field. We don’t know what will happen to us,” said Jagannath Behera (55) of Tali Tamparsara village under Attabira block of Bargarh district.

“And, we are well aware what is going to happen and how we will be exploited for the reason of undervaluation of paddy and discoloured paddy,” Behera added.

Paddy apart, all the cash crops also meet the same fate not only in the command area but all over the western Odisha and areas coming under the northern revenue division. Tomato, ladies finger, bitter guard, brinjal, parbal, pumkin and all other green vegetables are totally damaged, as is seen.

“However, a survey is being made in the field to assess loss and payment of input subsidy to the farmers will be considered as per norms,” informed RDC Niranjan Sahu .

Crop loss apart, many trees have been uprooted and electricity connections have been disrupted in many places, which has emerged as other problems for the locals. And due to Corona restrictions, labourers are not available for revival works.

Title: Watermelon crop damaged in K’jhar by hailstorm
Article:
After many people were thrown out of jobs because of closure of the local mines with introduction of mechanised mining in the Joda-Barbil mining sector, they tried their luck in the agriculture sector as an alternative source of income to maintain their family.

Accordingly, keeping an eye on the local markets, Joda, Barbil, Champua, Keonjhar town and outside market of Chainbasa and Jamshedpur-Tata, 13 farmers of Ramchadrapur of Kandra GP under Joda block had ploughed 5 acres of land to grow watermelon and muskmelon, highly demanded items in the summer season. But as ill luck would have it, just at the time of reaping the harvests, lockdown was imposed. As a result, their produce could not be transported. Meanwhile, the thunderstorm and hailstorm on Tuesday last damaged all the crops. Many farmers have been left in utter miseries.

Title: Briefs
Article:
Helpline issued for Khordha migrants' registration

Khordha: The Khordha district administration has issued a helpline number for registration of Odia migrant workers who would return home from other States post lockdown. Intending persons can register themselves at https:/khordha.nic.in/registration-of-migrants/# or through phone number 06755-223178. They are required to fill up forms online for registration, informed the DRDA PD, Khordha.

VS Vidyalay holds corona awareness drive

Koraput: The VS Vidyalaya, Sunabeda organised an awareness programme on coronavirus preventions at Sunabeda in Koraput district on Thursday. School secretary Tanveer Alan, Principal SK Seth, Senior Vice-Principal PK Mishra, VP-I BC Dalai, VP-II Dr SC Mohapatra and some selected teachers partipated. Senior Librarian Shaik Ibrahim coordinated the programme.

Title: Sarpanch beaten up for opposing cricket game
Article:
The Sarpanch of Bhairabagada village under Muniguda block in Rayagada district was thrashed by a group of youths when he warned them against playing cricket amid the Covid-19 lockdown. Later, 25 youths were arrested in this connection after Sarpanch Digambar Sikka lodged a complaint at the Muniguda police station on Thursday. Sikka was returning from the panchayat office when he came across the youths playing cricket at an open field. He asked them to stop the game and get back to their houses to abide by the lockdown norms. However, the youths ignored him and continued playing.

As his repeated advices went unheeded, the Sarpanch warned the youths that he would call up police if they did not leave the place. Agitated by this, the youths attacked Sikka, leaving him seriously injured.

Title: Section 144 at Gorekhnath Temple
Article:
In view of rush to the famous Baba Gorekhnath Temple in Jagatsinghpur district for a Yajna on Sunday during the lockdown, the district administration has decided to impose Section 144 of CrPC at the shrine for eight days with effect from April 26 till May 3.

The customary Yajna is scheduled at the temple from April 26 to May 3. District Collector Sangram Keshari Mohapatra has ordered clamping of Section 144 to prevent undesirable consequences.

A notification issued from the Collector’s office stated that gatherings of more than four persons including priests and presence of outsiders on temple premises would be prohibited under the law during the religious event.

Title: Haryana Govt directs private schools to only charge tuition fees
Article:
Due to lockdown, Haryana Government has directed private schools to only charge tuition fees on a per month basis for the time being from students.

The other charges including building and maintenance funds, admission fees, computer fees and any other fees should not be charged. Any school found violating these directions shall be liable to face action, a spokesman of the school education department said on Friday.

Amid the Covid-19 crisis, all the district education officers and district elementary education officers in the state should strictly adhere to the directions issued by the school education department, he said in a statement.

The spokesman said that as per the directions, private schools have also been directed to abstain from increasing the monthly tuition fees and refrain from charging the transportation fees from the students during the lockdown period.

He said that no changes in prices should be made in school uniforms, text-books, workbooks, practice books, practical files.

Apart from this, no private school would add any hidden charges to the monthly fees, he said.

The spokesman further said that due to non-payment of fees, private schools would neither strike off a student's name from the school nor can they deny them access to online education.

Due to the lockdown, the income and livelihood sources of the common man were affected adversely and therefore keeping this in view, this decision had been taken, he informed.

All educational institutions in Haryana are closed till May 3 due to the lockdown restrictions in place across the state.

Title: Non-ration card holders to get kerosene
Article:
In view of the lockdown situation, the State Government has decided to provide kerosene oil also to non-ration card holders for their domestic use.

As per the decision, the non-ration card holders would be provided two litre of kerosene per family, informed Food Supplies and Consumer Welfare Minister Ranendra Pratap Swain.

The Food Supplies and Consumer Welfare Department has written to the district Collectors for distribution of balance stocks of kerosene oil of January-March 2020 to non-ration card holders.

“It is ascertained that there is 3,458 kl of SK oil available with the wholesalers and 98 kl SK oil with the fair price shops across the State as on 31.03.2020,” the Department said in the letter.

The Collectors have been directed to utilise the available kerosene for distribution to non-ration card holders at two litre per family on first-come-first-service at the rate fixed during March 2020.

With the move, over 17 lakh non-ration card holder families in the State would be benefited.

Title: KIIT, KISS help Tibetans in anti-corona fight
Article:
The KIIT and the KISS, which have already taken a series of initiatives to help people and the State Government in the battle against the COVID-19 pandemic, have now extended a helping hand to the Tibetan communities at Jiranga and Chandragiri in Gajapati district.

Though the COVID-19 pandemic is not an immediate concern in this far-flung area of Odisha, hunger and poverty remain an issue in many settlements in and around Chandragiri.

The KIIT and KISS family has provided basic essentials and grocery for at least a month to the Tibetans at Chandragiri and to the monks of Padmasambhava Mahavihara Monastery at Jirang,

Besides food, kits containing essential items like sanitisers, hand wash, sanitary napkins and masks were also provided on the advice of by KIIT and KISS founder and MP Achyuta Samanta.

Feminine hygiene products were handed over to the district administration for distribution among women and girls in Ganjam.

"This crisis is not going to pass soon; it will take its time. Each one of us is inextricably connected to each other. We can overcome these difficult and unimaginable days only by being together. The real war with corona is not now, it is also the aftermath,” said Dr Samanta while informing that their contact with the monastery dates back to a decade.

Guru Gyetrul Jigme Rinpoche, the head Lama of the monastery, has congratulated Dr Samanta for his thoughtful leadership and compassion.

Title: 5 fresh Covid-19 cases in Haryana, total count 275
Article:
Five fresh Covid-19 cases were reported from Gurgaon, Panipat and Rohtak as the number of coronavirus patients rose to 275 in Haryana on Friday. The positive cases in the state include 24 foreigners, according to the daily bulletin of the state health department. While Gurgaon reported two cases, taking the number of Covid-19 patients to 47 in the district, Panipat also reported two cases and Rohtak one. According to the bulletin, the number of active coronavirus cases in the state stands at 86, while 186 patients have been discharged and three have died.

As on Friday, the state has a recovery rate of 67.63 per cent, fatality rate of 1.09 per cent and Covid-19 positive rate of 1.62 per cent (proportion of positive cases to total tests conducted), according to the bulletin.

The rate of doubling of cases is 17 days in the state, while the number of tests being conducted per 10 lakh people is 743, it said. The worst-hit districts of the state are Nuh (57 cases), Gurgaon (47), Faridabad (43) and Palwal (34). As many as 18,445 samples have been tested in Haryana so far, of which 16,642 have tested negative, while the report of 1,928 samples is awaited. Of the 24 foreign nationals who tested positive, 14 were Italian tourists, 13 of whom have been discharged, while one elderly woman passed away recently, even though she had recovered from Covid-19. Of the total number of Covid-19 patients, 64 are from other states, according to the bulletin.

Title: Decentralisation, fiscal autonomy can do wonders
Article:
Just before the Panchayati Raj Diwas on April 24, the Odisha Government in an exemplary policy decision, and extraordinary step towards a meaningful act of democratic decentralisation, has delegated the Sarpanches with the power of district Collectors within their jurisdictions in accordance with the provisions of the Disaster Management Act,2005, read with the Epidemic Diseases Act 1897 and the Odisha Covid-19 regulation.

The entire exercise is done to effectively take policy decisions at gram panchayat level so as to contain corona infection and efficiently carry out the registration and quarantine exercises.

Surprisingly, so far Odisha remains the only State to do this. This is being said here to not only to highlight the democratic decentralisation of power in attaining effective and practical governance only at the level of Panchayati Raj Institutions as envisaged in the 73rd and 74th Constitutional Amendments, but to show, the essence of optimum democratic decentralisation across the federal structure in attaining good governance.

Over the last many weeks, as we have faced the worst humanitarian crisis of our times, one thing that has come to the forefront is the governance model and leadership in governance shown by the Chief Ministers of different States and the proactive role played by the bureaucracy across the country in policy designing and implementation, to contain the spread of the virus.

Some States have empowered the district administrations to take autonomous and independent decisions at their levels after understanding the ground realities. This is not only prudent but also pragmatic. With the citizens remaining indoors, the steps taken by the respective State Governments and the State machinery have indeed shown us that, ‘minimum Government and maximum Governance’ is not actually impossible. But it seems that, the crux lies in a pragmatic, effective democratic decentralisation of power at all levels.

In fact, much before the Union Government, the State Governments have taken crucial steps in containing, preventing and combating Covid-19 infection and its spread, both by significant policy designs and decisions and use of legal means such as invocation of Disaster Management Act, 2005 and Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897. The Governments of Odisha, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Karnataka have not only been doing pretty well in designing their policies to cater to the situation, but have effectively established communication with the public in conveying their decisions with clarity.

Man is to err, so it is obvious that, there have been instances of flaws in implementing the decisions but even then, the tailoring of the policies have been broadly welcome and have specifically addressed the local concerns, be it Bhilwara in Rajasthan or the Odisha story of effective containment, and many standalone Covid-19 hospitals within a short period of time. Any way, they have become the laboratories of policies and governance. May be, it is that face of the bureaucracy and political leadership which we have least seen before, as the role they are playing now as ‘founts of reasoned authority’.

However, even though the State Governments have shown extraordinary leadership but there has always been a boundary imposed by the federal arrangement. According to experts, under such a federal arrangement there has always been firstly, a hindrance before the State Governments to have access to funds and therefore are often forced to design their own welfare packages; secondly, the criticalities of public finance management system which pose a bottleneck in procuring medical equipment and other essential healthcare products and thirdly, access to essential goods and services where it is supposed to reach them through a pan India process of production, transportation and supply chain. So, it is time to do away with such limitations, and the State Governments and local bodies are empowered to take much of such managerial exercises and the Union Government is to simply monitor the broad network of such activities.

Indian federalism as understood from the premises of the Indian Constitution has always been about equal partnership between the Centre and the States. The seventh Schedule has clearly demarcated the domains of action as regards legislation and consequent implementation and administration between the State and the Central Governments, while matters of national importance have remained with the Central Government. Subjects like agriculture, law and order, public health and sanitation have remained with the States and they have been absolutely vested with State ’s domain of activity.

The intent behind such provisions have been even farther than what is imagined of, being equal players in policy, legislation and administration to fiscal autonomy of the States in order to structure and implement policies according to the necessities at the ground level of the particular demographic setup. However, in practice, things have been quite different from the theory envisaged in the Constitution, as truly said by the Supreme Court in SR Bommai v. Union of India, that is, the Centre has always treated States as mere “appendages of the Centre”.

But the current crisis that we are facing now has made us go decentralised. The repeated conversation through video conferencing between the Prime Minister and the Chief Ministers, most importantly the address by the Prime Minister to Sarpanches across India, are nothing but the growing realisation by those in the helm of the affairs that, it is wiser, effective and practical to decentralise power in the sake of better and optimum governance.

Having said so, it is also important to understand that, the States apart from greater administrative autonomy should have increased share in total tax revenues to handle such situations, with the strength and vigour which is essentially rooted in financial strength. As recommended by the 14th Finance Commission the States should get an increased share out of the total tax revenues from 32 percent to 42 percent. However, on the contrary, what we have seen in the recent past is the increase in States contribution in various Centrally Sponsored Schemes.

It is not difficult to understand now that, democratic decentralisation of power, transparency and financial autonomy at all levels of governance can better our prospects not only in the current moment of corona crisis but in the long run as an efficient and vibrant democracy and economy.

(The writer is a lawyer and public policy expert. He can be reached at sjyotiranjan3@gmail.com.)

Title: 1 more patient recovered in Chd, recovery rate at 55%
Article:
One more positive Covid-19 patient recovered in Chandigarh on Friday, with the recovery rate of patients recorded in the city at 55 percent now, more than double the national average of 21 percent.

No fresh case of Covid-19 (coronavirus) has been reported in the city in the past four days. The total number of coronavirus cases stood at 27 till Friday evening while 15 out of them have already recovered.

The active cases in the city are now 12. Chandigarh has not recorded any Coronavirus related death.

According to the data released by Government of India recently, the rate of doubling of Covid-19 cases in Chandigarh stood at 25.4 days against the national average of 7.5 days.

“A 49 years old male, a resident of Sector 35 here who had a history of contact with nephews returning from Dubai and Singapore (residents of Punjab) has been cured and discharged from PGIMER on Friday,” said a senior UT officer.

He said that nine more Chandigarh contacts of Nayagaon (Punjab) positive patient who had been sampled at GMSH- 16 have been reported to be negative for coronavirus.

Punjab Governor and UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore on Friday expressed happiness at the recovery of another positive case in the city and applauded the role of doctors at PGIMER.

Notably, Chandigarh was declared a Covid-19 hotspot by Central Government on April 15 following which the UT Administration had declared the entire city as “containment zone” to contain the spread of Coronavirus.

A curfew was imposed in the city on March 24 to ensure social distancing amid Coronavirus pandemic and will remain in force till May 3.

So far, a part of Sector 30 B and Kacchi colony, Dhanas in Chandigarh has been declared as “affected pockets” and completely sealed to stop the infection. Around 1100 households live in Kacchi Colony, Dhanas while 590 families live in a part of Sector 30 B. A total of five positive cases have been reported from these affected areas.

Till Friday evening, a total of 638 samples have been tested so far while the report of seven was awaited till the filing of this report. As a precautionary measure, 2150 people have been put in home quarantine, out of which 1531 have completed the quarantine period till now.

Notably, the first positive case of Covid-19 was reported on March 19 in the city.

PGIMER team lined up outside NHE to cheer up Covid-19 cured patient

PGIMER team lined up outside the Nehru Hospital Extension (NHE) Block, designated as Covid Hospital, to cheer when a 49 years old positive patient from Chandigarh was discharged, giving hope to others fighting their battle of Covid-19 on Friday.

As PGIMER team ushered him towards the exit, the local resident of Sector 35 here was reunited with his family after nearly 21 days in PGIMER.

The patient was admitted in GMSH, Sector 16 on March 30 where he was tested Covid -19 positive. Later, he was shifted to PGIMER on April 3.

PGIMER Director Jagat Ram said, “The local resident has made an incredible recovery and the joyful moment of his discharge marks a positive milestone for PGIMER, which has been caring for all the positive Covi-19 patients in addition to SARI, ILI and non-Covid patients not only from the tricity but also from the adjoining neighbouring states.”

He said, “Today’s discharge marks the successful recovery of seventh Covid-19 positive patient from PGIMER’s dedicated Covid hospital.”

Giving details of the cured patient, Prof. Pankaj Malhotra, Department of Internal Medicine, PGIMER said, “The decision to discharge the patient from the hospital was taken by the treating team, which met and examined the results of his samples that had tested negative for two successive tests, a necessary pre-condition for a patient to be declared cured.”

Title: Centre appreciates Haryana’s Covid response, says Anil Vij
Article:
The Centre on Friday praised Haryana's Covid-19 response, lauding its performance on multiple parameters including the recovery rate and better-than-national doubling rate, State Health Minister Anil Vij said.

He said that Union Health Minister Dr Harsh Vardhan, who held a meeting on the Covid-19 situation with State Health Ministers over videoconferencing, was appreciative of the steps taken by Haryana.

“He appreciated the way Haryana has handled the situation. He was impressed when we informed him that our State's recovery rate was 67.63 per cent. He said it was a good sign. I also informed him that as of today, the state has 86 active Covid patients, the rate of doubling of infections has now increased from 13.5 days to 17 days, while tests per million being conducted were 743, and fatality rate was 1.09 per cent,” Vij said.

The national doubling rate stood at 10 days as on Friday.

Vij said that none of the patients admitted in hospitals in the state is in ICU or has needed ventilator support, adding early detection of cases has helped. He appreciated the role of doctors, nurses and paramedics in taking care of the patients and praised the police force for effectively implementing the lockdown.

The Haryana Health Minister said that during the meeting, the state was told not to use rapid testing kits, as has already been advised by the India Council of Medical Research, the country’s apex medical research body.

Vij said he brought to the Health Ministry's notice that Haryana had procured 25,000 rapid test kits from a South Korean company and it was not using the Chinese ones, but the state was asked to put these also on hold for the time being.

He said over 46 lakh people have been screened for the virus in the state. As many as 9,997 people have complained of some symptoms like difficulty in breathing and the state wanted to use the rapid test kits of the South Korean company for screening them, he said.

Vij said he apprised the Union Health Minister that the Haryana Government on Monday ordered a probe after four samples reported positive for corona virus by a private laboratory tested negative in confirmation tests done at government centres.

“I said the results of this lab were found not correct when samples of the four patients from Ambala district came negative in confirmation tests done at different government labs. I told the minister that it can create havoc in the state if people who are negative turn positive in this manner,” said Vij.

He said Harsh Vardhan has assured that the ICMR will look into the issue and do the needful. As fallout of the incident, Vij said that a committee has been constituted to inspect all the five ICMR-approved private labs in the state. “This committee may visit the premises of the private labs once in 10 days to have on-the-spot assessment. This committee will report to the Director of Health Services,” an official order said.

Meanwhile, Vij said that a central team visited some hospitals and containment zones in the State.

Title: Storm damages trees, power infra in B'swar
Article:
Baleswar district bore the brunt of nature’s fury amid 60 hours shutdown attributed to Corona virus as strong cyclonic wind ripped through the district causing massive damages. Hundreds of trees and mobile towers and electric poles were uprooted, besides the power supply lines were severed.

There is complete breakdown of power supply following thunderstorm accompanied with hails ever since it occurred in the forenoon. Several key roads of the town were blocked while cutting and removing of tree debris was underway. However, neither human injuries nor causalities were reported from any part of the district till the filing of the report.

Superintending Engineer, Nesco, BS Parida said, “Hundreds of trees were uprooted and fell on the supply lines. The tree cutting was on and poles were erected. It would take time. Most likely by late evening, the supply would be restored.”

The residents of the district are forced to be indoor as the State Government enforced more stringent measures , after witnessing spike in the number of positive cases.

The district administration in the 60 hour period has intensified the tracing of people across all blocks and GPs who have returned from West Bengal. Besides it sanitized the containment zones and its adjacent areas, besides other vulnerable pockets.

Title: CUO extends applications date to May 23
Article:
The last date for submission of online application forms for admission into various undergraduate, postgraduate and research programmes offered by the Central University of Odisha (CUO) through CUCET 2020 has been extended till May 23, said a release.

In view of the lockdown situation all over the country to prevent possible spread of COVID 19, the last date for submission of online application has been extended from April 11 to 25 earlier and further it was extended to May 23.

Candidates can fill and submit the online application form at www.cucetexam.in.

The entrance examination will be conducted in 141 centres for under graduate and post graduate programmes and in 47 centres for research programmes in various cities across the country. As per the notification of the CUCET the applicants can choose any examination centre convenient to them.

In Odisha there are 13 exam test centres for UG and PG such as Angul, Baleswar, Bhadrak, Bhawanipatna, Bhubaneswar, Brahmapur, Cuttack, Keonjhar, Koraput, Malkangiri, Paralakemundi, Raurkela and Sambalpur and three centres for research programme such as Cuttack, Bhubaneswar and Sambalpur.

The entrance examinations for all UG and PG programmes scheduled to be held on May 30 and 31 and for research programmes June 6 and 7 are postponed and revised dates will be notified later in the university website as well as CUCET website, said the release.

Title: Social distancing flouted in Brahmapur
Article:
In spite of the best efforts and repeated requests of the Ganjam district administration to maintain social distancing particularly at business locations and hospitals in Brahmapur, the guidelines are flouted by the people in several places.

The physical distancing norms are hardly maintained in the places like outdoor ticket counter as well as the medicine delivery counters of different departments of the MKCG Medical College Hospital.

On the other hand, the security staffs on duty in these places are unable to control the crowds. The hospital authorities reportedly have instructed to install temporary barricades in these places within three days to tackle the crowd, said MKCG Hospital Dr Santosh Kumar Mishra.

According to information available, the medical authorities so far have tested the swab of 90 corona suspects out of which two are from the MKCG Medical College and the remaining are from different parts of district. The swab of all the suspects was sent to the RMRC in Bhubaneswar for testing. While four corona suspects were admitted into the isolation ward of the MKCG Hospital earlier, two more suspects were admitted in to the isolation ward on Thursday raising the number of patients to six who are currently under treatment, Dr Mishra said.

Meanwhile, as an effective preventive measure, the district administration has imposed restrictions on physical movement of persons in the city after 12 pm. It is found that only 25 percent of the shops of the city are transacting their business and closing their shops before noon.

In spite of lockdown, the pro welfare measures are at place as usual. According to information available, ration received from different voluntary and social organisations have been distributed to 20,000 families and 22,000 beneficiaries have received their amount. Each family was given rice, five kg dal, refine oil, flattened rice and sugar for their survival.

Notably, 43,000 families of Brahmapur so far have been included under Food Securities Act to avail benefits. The beneficiaries were given rice and wheat for three months during first phase of distribution and during last three days each of the 22,000 families were now given cash of Rs 1, 000 each, said Brahmapur Municipal (BeMC) Commissioner Chakravarti Singh Rathore.

The district BJP also distributed dry foods and masks to the poor families residing in and around Kumbhar Sahi and Malikeswar temple on Thursday in which Old Brahmapur Mandal president Binayak Rath, former district president of the party KC Pati; district Yuva Morcha president Sidhanta Gangadev; district vice-present Prabhat Sadangi were present.

Meanwhile, the city police have succeeded in unearthing guthka worth crores of rupees by intensifying raids on various guthka godowns in Desibehera Street and Jena Street of the city and seized guthka worth crores during last three days here, sources said.

The raids are further being intensified by police at guthka godowns at Mahabir complex, Rath complex, and Sree complex of Jena Street to curb the illegal guthka business and its unlawful hoarding in the city, sources said.

Title: Intense contact tracing begins in 3 hotspot dists
Article:
The State Government on Friday stepped up contact tracing in coronavirus hotspots in Baleswar, Bhadrak and Jajpur districts to identify the people who have recently returned from other States, especially West Bengal.

Notably, the Government has imposed a 60-hour complete shutdown from 10 pm on Thursday till April 26 in the three districts following a spurt in the Covid-19 cases.

With five more person found infected with the virus in Bhadrak district on Friday, the three districts together accounted for 39 of the total 94 positive cases in the State.

While Bhadrak and Jajpur have 12 confirmed cases each, Baleswar has 10 patients.

The administrations of the three districts with help of sarpanches and urban local body functionaries have launched a drive to trace the people who had come in contact with coronavirus patients.

It has come to light that almost all coronavirus patients in the three districts either had a travel history to West Bengal or they had come in contact with returnees from other States.

As a measure to prevent entry of people from Bengal, DGP Abhay said 37 roads connecting Baleswar district to the neighbouring State are now manned by police.

Local panchayat and urban local body functionaries are identifying the people who have recently returned from other States.

Bhadrak district Collector Gyana Das said the administration has been focusing on Basudevpur block as the area has reported seven cases. The district administration in Jajpur has already prepared a list of people who have a recent travel history to other States, including West Bengal, Collector Ranjan Kumar Das said.

“We have already started putting people coming in contact with COVID-19 patients in quarantine. Their samples will be collected today,” he said.

Title: 5 more positive in Bhadrak with West Bengal links
Article:
Five more persons tested COVID-19 positive in Bhadrak district on Friday, taking the tally in the State to 94.

While a case had been reported earlier in the day, four were reported later.

The Information and Public Relations Department, in a tweet, informed that a 40-year-old man, a 29- year-old youth, a 41–year-old man and a 24- year-old youth were found positive in Tihidi and Dhamnagar blocks of the district.

All of them are West Bengal returnees. Earlier in the day, a 40-year–old man had also tested positive in the district. He had also returned from West Bengal.

With the fresh cases, the total tally of virus patients rose to16 in the district.

The district is now already under a 60-hour shutdown and strict surveillance and contact tracing of patients are going on by the administration.

Meanwhile, the State Government has ramped up the sample tests to contain the virus spread. The State had a record number of 2,474 Covid-19 RT-PCR tests in the last 24 hours.

Title: COVID-19 cases mount to 48 in U’khand
Article:
The number of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) in Uttarakhand mounted to 48 on Friday with State health department reporting one patient of the disease in Nainital district. This 40 year old patient is a resident of Haldwani and had come into contact with a Corona positive person. The department had taken his swab sample on April 9 which was found negative for the disease. He was being kept at institutional quarantine by the authorities and after completion of 14 mandatory days, his second sample was sent for COVID-19 test which was found positive on the day. After his sample was found positive, he was sent to the isolation facility of the government medical college, Haldwani.

The additional secretary medical health and family welfare department, Yugal Kishore Pant said that one more patient of the disease has recovered from the disease on Friday as second sample of his was found negative. He said that 25 patients out of 48 have recovered from the disease in the state. Pant said that reports of 361 suspected patients were received by the department on Friday till 7.00 pm and out of them one was found positive. He said that reports of 327 samples are still awaited by the department.

The authorities have so far taken swab samples of 4767 suspected patients for COVID-19 test. On Friday samples of 285 suspected patients were taken and sent to the lab for test. From Haridwar district 92 samples were collected while 82 samples were collected from Udham Singh Nagar district.

In Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital, 12 positive patients of COVID-19 are currently admitted while seven are undergoing treatment at Mela hospital, Haridwar. Similarly three patients are admitted in government medical college, Haldwani and one in Military Hospital (MH), Dehradun.

Pant added that out of five districts of state where COVID- 19 cases have so far been reported no case has been reported from last 30 days from Pauri district. Similarly in Almora, no case has so far been reported from last 19 days. The authorities have kept Dehradun, Haridwar and Nainital districts in red zone, here 25, 7 and 10 cases respectively have been reported so far. In the state the authorities have completely sealed 11 localities for being hot spots of the disease. In Dehradun there are seven hotspots while three are in Haridwar and one in Nainital district.

Title: Naveen speaks to Modi over Rath Yatra
Article:
Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik on Friday held telephonic discussions with Prime Minister Narendra Modi about organising Lord Jagannath’s Rath Yatra in Puri this year as there is an element of uncertainty over the centuries-old festival following the Covid-19 outbreak.

While apprising Modi of the Covid-19 situation in the State, Patnaik reportedly informed the Prime Minister that about 10 lakh devotees assemble in Puri to celebrate the mega festival every year. The two leaders discussed as to how to maintain social distancing when a large number people would gather for the Car Festival, which is scheduled on June 23.

Meanwhile, Jagannath culture researcher Bhaskar Mishra said the Rath Yatra has been held uninterrupted since 1736.

Opposition parties Congress and BJP have urged the State Government to take a decision on holding the Rath Yatra at the earliest.

According to the schedule, construction of chariots of the deities should begin on April 26 and Snana Yatra, the annual ceremonial bathing ritual of the deities at the temple, will be held in early June.

The Jagannath Temple has remained closed for devotees since March 22 though the rituals at the shrine are followed by the priests as usual.

Meanwhile, the Shree Jagannath Temple Administration (SJTA) has begun discussions on the issue with Govardhan Peeth Shankaracharya Swami Nischalananda Saraswati and Puri Gajapati Maharaja Dibyasingha Deb.

“The final decision will be taken in accordance with the views of the Shankaracharya,” said servitor Ramachandra Dasmohapatra, who is a member of the managing committee.

However, Shreemandir chief servitor Janardan Pattajoshi Mohapatra has suggested that the Rath Yatra, if organised this year, should be a low-key event to follow the tradition.

In a letter to the Shankaracharya, he wrote, “If the lockdown period continues up to the day of Rath Yatra, we would like to submit that the festival must still be performed for the important reason that the Rath Yatra constitutes not just a festive procession but an important ritual/event.”

Title: Covid-19 test to start at GDMC from today
Article:
The testing of samples for COVID-19 would start at Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) from Saturday. On Friday the microbiology lab of the medical college was given formal approval by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) to start testing for COVID-19. The Principal of the GDMC, Dr Ashutosh Sayana said that the speed of testing of the samples in the state would increase with the GDMC lab becoming operational for COVID-19 tests. He said that the lab is ready and the training to the staff has been given for testing of swab samples of suspected patients. The Principal said that the college would receive the test kits by Friday evening. He added that six microbiologists of GDMC would conduct the tests.

After start of COVID-19 tests at GDMC, the state would have three centres of test of samples for the disease in government sector. A private lab ( Aahuja lab) in Dehradun has also been authorised to conduct COVID-19 tests.

At present the testing facilities of COVID-19 are available only at the laboratory of department of microbiology of Government Medical College, Haldwani and All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Rishikesh. Till last month Lab of Haldwani was the only facility in the state for COVID-19. On March 31, the AIIMS Rishikesh also started doing the tests.

The confirmatory test of the COVID-19 involves detection of Ribo Nucleic Acid (RNA) of the virus by the Real Time (RT) -PCR method.

Title: No rituals outside temple in lockdown: Gajapati
Article:
Puri Gajapati Maharaja Dibyasingha Deb on the day said no rituals can take place outside the Shreemandir during the lockdown.

After chairing a Shreendir Managing Committee meeting via videoconference, he said that as per the guidelines framed by both Centre and Odisha Government, religious congregation cannot to be held at any temple. Accordingly, the Chandan Yatra of Lord Jagannath to commence from Akshaya Trutitya (April 26), would be conducted without devotees.

“Even, the process for the Rath Yatra that commences from Akshaya Trutitya cannot take place till May 3,” he said.

About the uncertainty of holding Rath Yatra, he said a decision would be taken after consulting the Shakaracharya of Puri.

“In context of conducting a religious event, only a religious guru can guide us as per religious scriptures and tradition. It has been decided that the Managing Committee members and servitors of Lord Jagannath will visit Jagadguru Shankaracharya this evening and seek his guidance on ritualistic prospects of forthcoming event,” he added.

Title: UT begins special screening of jail inmates in Burail Model Jail
Article:
The Chandigarh Administration on Friday begun a special screening of prisoners for coronavirus in Model Jail, Burail here.

At present, there are a total of 1007 inmates against the sanctioned strength of 1120 in the Burail prison.

As per the data with the Administration, there are a total of 420 convicts including 420 male and 20 females. Undertrials prisoners are 583 including 547 males and 36 females. There are four children in the prison as well.

Foreign nationals include six while convicted prisoners who are presently on parole are four, stated the data.

Manoj Parida, Adviser to Administrator on Friday said that a special drive is being conducted for examining the inmates in the Burail jail, so that there is no outbreak of Covid-19 in the jail premises.

Visitors were banned in jail in March in view of Coronavirus pandemic.

Meanwhile, the UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore on Friday appealed to the citizens to strictly follow the curfew orders and follow the hygiene practices as recommended by the doctors,

so that the spread of coronavirus could be contained in the city.

He also expressed happiness that the number of active cases has been reduced to 12 in the city.

It was informed that Chandigarh ranks third amongst the highest recovery states/union territories.

According to the latest data, the doubling rate of corona cases in Chandigarh is 30.26 days; as compared to national average of 8.6 days. Earlier on Monday, the rate of doubling of Covid-19 cases in Chandigarh stood at 25.4 days.

The Administrator thanked the doctors, health workers and the entire administrative hierarchy for the success in restricting the spread of Covid-19. He emphasized that regular screening of vendors, sanitation workers, delivery boys, hawkers etc. should be carried out throughout the city.

It was informed that a new Control and Command Centre has been set up in Municipal Corporation office, which will regulate the anti-Covid operations in the city. Also, the entire workforce of Municipal Corporation has been completely screened.

The Administrator was also apprised that more than 6,000 senior citizens have been personally contacted during curfew period and their grievances have been settled. It was further informed that a mechanism has been devised for returning of impounded vehicles through online applications in the city.

Title: 2 more Bhadrak GPs declared containment zones
Article:
As the number of Covid-19 positive patients is on the rise in Bhadrak district with one more fresh case reported from Basudevpur block in last 24 hours, the district administration on Friday declared containment zones in two more gram panchayats (GPs) to break the chain of spread of the deadly virus.

As many as 10 villages coming under the two GPs of Arandua and Brahmanigaon under Basudevpur block have been kept under containment. Random sample collection and sanitisation activities would be undertaken in the confined areas.

With this, movement of public has been strictly restricted in the zones. All shopping establishments would remain closed while supply of essential commodities and medical requirements would be ensured through teams formed by the district administration. All Government and private institutions within the containment zones would remain closed.

So far, 12 positive Covid-19 cases have been reported in the district with all the patients having travel history to different parts of India.

Earlier, five GPs were declared as containment zones in the district.

Title: PUNJAB TO AGAIN RAISE SALE OF LIQUOR ISSUE WITH PM
Article:
Punjabis have a reason to keep up their spirits. A day after Centre’s decision against allowing liquor sale in the State, Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh has resolved to once again discuss the issue of “prohibition” with the Prime Minister Modi on Monday for enabling the people of the State to raise a toast in the days of low feeling.

Unhappy with the Centre’s denial, Capt Amarinder on Friday said that he would again raise the issue with the Prime Minister during the scheduled video conferencing on Monday.

At the same time, he questioned the connection between the spread of the novel coronavirus and the sale of liquor — which the state has been demanding to generate revenue amidst fiscal crunch.

“I will again raise the issue of reopening alcohol business to generate revenue during Monday’s video conference with the Prime Minister,” said the Chief Minister during a webinar with nearly 100 industrialists and senior executives, foreign envoys and others on Friday.

Pointing out that Punjab was a small state, he asked how the Centre expected it to cope with the current crisis without GST (Goods and Services Tax) and without liquor sales.

Punjab had made a formal request after the Union Ministry of Home Affairs, in its consolidated revised guidelines on April 15 for the second phase of lockdown that runs till May 3, categorically stated that no liquor shop will be permitted to open anywhere in the country. Only a day before, Punjab’s plea to resume sale of liquor in the state amidst the lockdown was rejected by the Union Ministry.

The guidelines stated, there will be a strict “ban” on sale of liquor, gutka and tobacco during the lockdown, and no permission was either given to bars to remain open during the lockdown period.

After the guidelines, two northeastern states — Assam and Meghalaya — which had earlier allowed sale of liquor in the first phase of lockdown from March 25 to April 14, also ordered them to shut down starting April 15.

Questioning the logic behind closing liquor shops, Capt Amarinder said: “What’s the connection between coronavirus and liquor sale? Coronavirus spreads through mucus. You have allowed vegetables to be sold in the open. But, what’s the logic behind banning the sale of liquor in sealed bottles? This is affecting state revenue.”

Capt Amarinder pointed that Punjab has incurred revenue losses of Rs 6,200 crore because of the ban on liquor sales during the lockdown period, while Centre is also not ready to assist us and releasing state’s pending GST arrears.

Punjab’s GST compensation of approximately Rs 4,400 crore for the last four months – from December 2019 to March 2020 – was pending for disbursement by the Union Government.

On the other hand, the state’s committed expenditure — including debt servicing, pensions, salaries, relief measures for Covid-19, healthcare and infrastructure — is budgeted at

Rs 7,301 crore for April 2020.

As Capt Amarinder would raise the issue with the Prime Minister during the video conference meeting, he is expected to be joined by the Chief Ministers of other states too including Delhi and Kerala. Even Haryana too is keen to start the liquor business.

Liquor sales are a significant source of revenue for Punjab, which is currently facing a severe financial situation without the Centre’s assistance.

In fact, instances of liquor smuggling are being reported from different parts of the state. Only a day before, an illegal liquor distillation plant in Khanna was busted, with the arrest of five men and seizure of 1,857 cartons of illicit liquor along with machines, vehicles, and Rs 5.8 lakh cash.

Several states are keen the Centre allows sale of liquor. BJP-ruled Assam and Meghalaya had ordered opening of distilleries and liquor sales to resume when a three-week lockdown was about to end on April 14 but was extended till May 3.

Title: ‘Ensure health insurance for journalists’
Article:
Expressing concern over a large number of journalists in Mumbai testing positive for Covid-19, Union minister Pratap Sarangi on Friday urged the Centre to introduce a health insurance scheme for scribes covering the pandemic in line with the one for frontline health workers.

In the last few weeks, several journalists in Chennai, Bhopal and other places have also tested positive, Sarangi said in a letter to Union Information and Broadcasting Minister Prakash Javadekar.

He said scribes who have been infected with the deadly virus should be assured of quality treatment free of cost besides job security and salary during their absence from duty.

“The government should make provision for a health insurance scheme for journalists in the line with the insurance for frontline health workers,” Sarangi said in the letter.

He also urged the Centre to come out with specific guidelines for field journalists covering the pandemic such as mandatory use of personal protective equipments (PPEs) and report from designated sanitised areas to discharge their duty and ensure that people get crucial and timely information.

Title: Maoist camp busted following encounter
Article:
Police have busted a Maoist camp in the Chandli Reserve Forest near Sunamudi village under the Lathore police station in Balangir district following an encounter.

Acting on a tipoff about the Maoist presence in the Chandali Forest, two Special Operations Group (SOG) teams were rushed to the spot on April 22 night. On Thursday morning, the security personnel managed to locate the camp belonging to the BBM Division of Maoists.

But when they asked the ultras to surrender, they were fired upon. Following which there was an exchange of fire. Police fired about 20 rounds but the rebels managed to escape from the spot taking advantage of the thick forests and hilly terrain.

Later, police recovered some ammunition, daily use items like grocery, utensils from the spot, said Balangir SP Sandeep Sampat here on Friday.

When asked about casualties and injuries to anyone, Sampat said nothing can be said conclusively now.

Title: Schroff awardee Das' death anniv held
Article:
The 18th death anniversary of noted freedom fighter, Odisha's first pharmacist and first ML Schrof national awardee Jagannath Das was observed here at his New Barracks Street residence here on Friday.

Due to the lockdown, the usual commemorative meeting was cancelled and the ceremony was confined only to his family members.

The State's first pharmacy college named the College of Pharmaceutical Sciences was established at Mohuda here under the leadership and professional guidance of Das. He had also played a key role in formation of two more pharmaceutical institutions, the Roland College Pharmaceutical Science at Brahmapur and the Pharmacy College at Puri.

Das is also remembered for his amicable approaches and myriad social works. He was conferred “Lifetime Achievement Award” in 2001 by the then Governor MM Rajendran, said his son PK Das.

Title: 3 Ganjam GPs get nat’l award
Article:
On the occasion of the National Panchayati Raj Day on Friday, three gram panchayats (GPs) in Ganjam district were conferred with the National GP Award 2020 in different categories.

While Kainchapur GP of Ganjam block was awarded in the category of Best Development Plan in Odisha, Badaborasingi under Belaguntha block was awarded as Best Child-Friendly GP in the State. Besides, Podamari GP under Sanakhemundi block received the Nanaji Deshmukh Rashtriya Gaurav Gram Sabha Puraskar. Earlier in the day, Prime Minister Narendra Modi interacted with Sarpanchs of all GPs across the country through videoconferencing.

Title: DA increment of Uttarakhand employees, pensioners frozen
Article:
In view of the financial constraint faced by the Government due to the ongoing battle against COVID-19, the Uttarakhand Government has put on hold the increase in the Dearness Allowance (DA) for its employees till July 2021.

The DA of the employees would remain frozen at 17 percent of their basic pay during this period. The State Government toed the line of the central government which a day earlier had taken a similar decision.

The Government had given an increment of 4 percent in the DA in the month of January this year. This increment would now not be given to the employees. Apart from it the usual six monthly increments in the DA would also not be given to the employees till July 2021. In an order the Secretary finance, Amit Singh Negi said that due to the crisis precipitated by the spread of COVID-19, the State Government has decided not to pay the increment in DA to its employees which were due from January 2020. The order added that the increment in the DA due in July 2020 and January 2021 would also not be given to the employees. This order would re main applicable on the employees and pensioners of state government. A total of 3.5 lakh state government employees and pensioners would be affected by this measure of the state government.

The decision to freeze the DA has not gone down well with the employees though they are not very vocal against the decision. “We understand the position of government but it would have been better had the government consulted the employee organisation before taking the decision. We would have also suggested better ways to save the money to the government. Further by reducing the money to the employees the markets would be affected,’’ said Arun Pandey, a prominent employee leader.

Title: SER, SERWWO manufacture PPE Kits
Article:
In order to curb the spread of COVID-19, Kharagpur Division of South Eastern Railway (SER) in association with SER Women's Welfare Organization (SERWWO), Kharagpur Division has started manufacturing PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) Kits for support of railway Doctors, Paramedical staff and Healthcare personnel. The PPE Kit includes Face Cover, Eye Shield, NS-95 Mask, Coverall Gown with Hood, Shoe Cover, Gloves and others.

Informing this by issuing press release SER said that this In-House production of PPE Kits is being done at “Hunar Center for Stitching &Embroidery” under the supervision of SER Women's Welfare Organization (SERWWO) and Mechanical Department of Kharagpur Division. It has been decided to produce 1000 PPE initially. Till now Kharagpur Division in association with SERWWO has manufactured 225 units of PPE Kit along with shoe covers.

The material used is non-woven polypropylene barrier fabric, which is impermeable to blood and bodily fluids. The PPE design and material are certified from DRDE, Gwalior. After stitching, the PPE Kits with shoe covers are sealed in plastic bags with markings of size, serial number and date of manufacturing. Social distancing, thermal screening and sanitizing are ensured during production of the PPE Kits. Regular inspections are also being done to ensure quality.

In addition to above, reusable masks are also being manufactured by SERWWO at “Hunar Centre”, Kharagpur. WWO has already manufactured 7000 reusable face masks, out of which 3000 masks have been handed over to the employees of Kharagpur Division. SERWWO is targeting for manufacturing of 30000 reusable face masks. Hand Sanitizers are also being manufactured in Kharagpur Division at Diesel Shed, Divisional Railway Hospital, EMU Car Shed at Santragachi and Electronic Loco Shed at Santragachi. Already, 600 liters of sanitizer have been manufactured In-house till now.

With a view to fulfill the commitment for the uninterrupted supply of essential commodities in every nook and corner of the Country during nation-wide lockdown in the wake of Corona virus pandemic, South Eastern Railway has already taken all out efforts to run freight trains with essential commodities on top priority towards different destinations in the country.

SER, during the month of April from April 1 to April 22 unloaded 62 rakes containing 1.56 lakh tonnes of essential commodities such as 40 rakes of rice, 14 rakes of wheat, 5 rakes of vegetable oil, one rake of salt and another 2 rakes containing 6700 Kiloliters of Petroleum product at different places of this railway covering the states of West Bengal, Jharkhand and Odisha.

In addition to above during this nation wise lockdown, this railway has already run 281 trips of Parcel Express trains carrying high priority essential commodities such as food items, medicines, medical equipment including PPE kits, face masks, sanitizers to various destinations to and fro from Shalimar, Howrah, Tatanagar from April 2 to April 22. This amounts to 3,562 tonnes of parcel traffic containing 1,25,727 number of packages to and for different cities and towns of the Country.

This challenging gigantic task has been undertaken by the SER with the active participation of a dedicated workforce of front line warriors such as Loco Pilots, Guards, Trackmen, Station Masters, Parcel handling staff working at stations and divisional headquarters who are rendering their yeoman services to the nation in this crisis time.

Title: JPPC head distributes masks, gloves among vendors
Article:
President of Jharkhand Pradesh Professional Congress, Aditya Vikram Jaiswal, distributed masks and globes among vegetable vendors of Lalpur on Friday to prevent the spread of Corona epidemic. During this time, members of the Professional Congress reached the 150 vegetable vendors sitting from Lalpur to Distillery Bridge and distributed masks and gloves. He also explained the advantages of their use and the methods of wearing and opening.

Giving masks and gloves to vegetable vendors, Jaiswal said that vigilance, caution and awareness of all of you are very important. In the purchase and sale of vegetables, one has to face many and the spread of coronavirus in the capital Ranchi is increasing every day, so it is necessary for the people to use masks and gloves. He said that awareness is necessary to protect every person and society from coronavirus disease. Jaiswal said that it is the greatest human religion to serve the poor, needy in this disaster of Corona epidemic. He has appealed to all the citizens to stay in the house for the sake of country interest and observe Lokdown. He said that people living in their homes at this time is equal to national service.

Amarjeet Singh, Rahul Roy, Rajiv Chaurasia, Gaurav Anand, Sonu Singh, Prem Kumar etc. were present on the occasion.

Title: MLA appeals for three months school fee waiver
Article: The Haridwar Rural MLA Swami Yatishwaranand has appealed that school fees not be charged for the months of April, May and June since the income of many parents have been stalled since March due to the lockdown enforced to contain the COVID-19 pandemic. Yatishwaranand said that he had talked to the Union Human Resource Development minister Ramesh Pokhriyal ‘Nishank’ and the state’s education minister Arvind Pandey about this issue. The MLA said that he had appealed through the social media that the school fees for three months should be waived off. He said that he would pursue the issue and try to get the fee waiver for three months.

Title: CCL gives foodgrains to needy in command areas
Article:
In a move to provide help to the people during the ongoing lockdown Central Coalfield Limited (CCL) is not only producing coal more than required but also it is distributing food grains among large numbers of people so that no one should sleep hungry during the period.

CCL has been working in coordination with the local administration in eights districts of the Jharkhand. The Company has provided about 100 quintals of food grains like rice, pulses, salt, wheat flour, mustard oil, soya bari, flattened rice, spices, potatoes, onions etc to the local administration for distribution among the needy during lockdown.

The Company has also supplied other relief materials like masks, sanitizers and others things to the administration to check spread of Corona virus. CCL has also distributed food grains packet withing the State to more than 12,000 families. CCL is continuing distribution of food grains and other relief works during the ongoing lockdown which is extended till May 3.

Apart from this CCL, a subsidiary of Coal India has set up dedicated helpline numbers (0651-2365999, 0651-2361013, 0651-2360606) so that any needy person staying in command areas of the Company can make calls during the lockdown and the Company will extend all possible support to them including arranging food grains packet and medical advice.

CCL is not only motivating the employees and stakeholders to play significant role in the Country’s fight against the Corona virus pandemic but ensuring that no one should sleep hungry in command areas of the Company during lockdown.

CMD CCL Gopal Singh has been in touch with Area General Mangers through video conference and other means of communication. He has issued necessary instruction that the employees must take all preventive measures like wearing hand gloves, mask and others while performing duties at work place and while coming to home.

Singh said that it is important to prevent oneself from this deadly virus so that he or she does not transmit to other healthy individual and then only family, society, Jharkhand and our Country could overcome from this unprecedented crisis.

CCL is ensuring in its command areas that no one sleeps hungry during the exercise to check the spread of Corona virus during lockdown. “We are distributing food packets comprising essential items like rice, pulses, spices and other items in all areas with support of district administration to ensure no one sleeps empty stomach during lockdown,” Singh said. He further added that the coal family has become a soldier in this corona war and working like every other citizen of this country to fight against the Corona virus.

The ongoing 21-day lockdown has extended till May, 3. During the first phase of 21-day lockdown, CCL has performed exemplary work and its employees worked as “front line warriors” and distributed food packets in command areas of the Company, which is spread out in eight districts of Jharkhand- Ranchi,

Ramgarh, Hazaribagh, Latehar, Palamu, Chatra, Giridih and Bokaro- by adhering norms of maintaining social distancing and other advisories issued by government from time to time.

Title: Increasing the reach of digital learning in India
Article:
The wave of digital learning reached India in 2016 with the launch of SWAYAM (Study Webs of Active-Learning for Young Aspiring Minds) platform by Ministry of Human Resource Development. However, the foundation was already laid down by NPTEL and e-PG Pathshala, a decade ago with the availability of e-contents in the form of audio-video, text etc with free availability for all.

The author remembers attending a workshop on open educational resources (OERs) in Faculty Development Centre (FDC) of HNB Garhwal University, Srinagar, with other faculty participants. Apart from many eye opening sessions, one got the essence of digital /blended/ flipped learning through OERs and SWAYAM Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs). During a session, professor Rajat Agarwal from the Department of Business Management, IIT Roorkee had said, “This train is going ahead and those who board early will reach the destination of the digital world earlier; digital education is the future.” Within a few months, I got two MOOC proposals approved by two different national coordinators. With the help of training extended by UGC/ MHRD in IIM Bangalore and NITTTR Chennai, the courses were developed. Both The two MOOCs ‘Academic Writing’ and ‘Industrial Pharmacy’ performed very well. Moreover, Academic Writing MOOC was ranked number one in July 2019 cycle with maximum exam registration. These were the happy moments which refreshed us after tiring journey of developing two MOOCs together. We had the feeling of “mission accomplished” but it was just the first insight of the entire story.

Just developing MOOCs was not serving the actual need of the education system. The awareness level even in urban areas about digital learning initiatives like SWAYAM is very low. Most of the universities and faculty members do not want to change the conventional teaching and learning process. The challenge was not the production but marketing of the same as a thumb rule of management. So, after checking the success and failure story of various platforms, one realised that having good intention without significant results takes even a major project down. It happened with many ICT initiatives of MHRD for the time being. Many of the e-contents were hardly viewed. When the government is spending huge amount of taxpayers’ money, the results must be tangible with fixed accountability. The success model of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT, US) and many world leaders of digital learning are just having commercial interest. But SWAYAM is carrying the Vishwaguru legacy forward.

SWAYAM, the digital platform of MHRD has a plethora of courses and contents for the learners of classes IX to PhD and even for the faculty members in the form of ARPIT (Annual Refresher Programme in Teaching). Moreover, 20 per cent of credits of a semester may be earned through SWAYAM MOOCs. The contents are used also for blended and flipped learning.

The challenge is to take SWAYAM to the grassroot level and to address the fear among faculty members that digital education is being disseminated to replace them. This will increase the willingness to accept even from the administrative part of the institutions. The awareness level must be identified in each region of the country and a need-based strategy must be planned to address the problem. In Uttarakhand, where connectivity and speed of the internet is the major challenge in many remote areas and even in an educational hub like Srinagar (Garhwal), a strong strategy must be planned based on the inputs and suggestions of the stakeholders of that area. Recently, the Uttarakhand Government has taken the initiative of establishing an e-learning lab in every government PG college. Now we have the courses, we have the experts, we have the contents, but what we don't have the users of this platform in the tune of our population of young learners. In COVID-19 scenario when the entire country is in lockdown, the importance of SWAYAM and SWAYAMPRABHA and other ICT -initiatives of MHRD, Government of India has been revalidated by the historic boom of its users. Amid the COVID -19 lockdown, the Indian Government has made it mandatory for all the DTH providers to telecast the SWAYAMPRABHA educational channels and this is a great step in increasing the reach of digital education to the larger population of the country. The need of the hour is to bring more and more regular classroom learners to SWAYAM. And the dissemination of this needs the support of every citizen of our country. At this moment one remembers what Rabindranath Tagore said 100 years ago- “Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high, where knowledge is free…”. In continuation of this spirit, can we take up the challenge to make knowledge accessible to all citizens and the next generation through digital learning?

(The author is an assistant professor, Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences at Garhwal University, Chauras campus)

Title: Let us connect with their soul
Article:
Namaste...health for all of us!

We, as humans have that innate propensity allowing our peculiarities squeeze out of ourselves when pressed in a water tight compartment. It is our coping mechanism first and later, a forte.

So this lockdown is a 'semicolon' in a 'polysyndeton'! ...I couldn't think of a better metaphor!

This read is far from how the pandemic has brought the economic arena to a turmoil, so chill !

We actually needed this. Driving high on a long haul , a sudden speed breaker!

While you were doing the dishes and thinking of the laundry, you were also feeling gratitude of having to do the dishes; which assures you of the grains in the house.
