While playing it up...cooking , mopping , sweeping etc... and recording, the jocular memes and other tuck on the social media... we know we are happy souls.

Souls!

There are species of 'souls' who, if were given even more flourishing senses, in the court of Mother Nature , would undisputingly win their claim on Earth .

There is this clan of yellow butterflies swarming my garden all day long. My husband, owing to the job he is in , has to move out in the city , tells me about these lemon coloured winged caterpillars being the new inhabitants of the town.

Adjacent to my house , stands a traffic light.

So, honk and beeps, wheel roar-rush , hooters hooting are the perennial deafening melodies we are ears to without a choice.

I repeat...'we are ears to...'

....were these noises defeaning 'only ' us !?!

I answer myself in a 'no'.

And these raptors and fledlings are so naive. Sans rancour , they returned.

Parrot, koel , pigeon and sparrow , yellow beaked joy , owl and crow.

Since when did they not belong here! And where were they all this while?

That they are here now, let us connect with their soul.

They don't seek food from us nor do they tax upon our lives. Only some calm.

This Earth is theirs as much.

So, dear yellow butterflies and chirpy birdies, joy abundant for all of us !

(The writer, Neha M. R. Aggarwal, is a lawyer by qualification and hails from Patiala, Punjab; now based in Ranchi)

Title: CM Rawat congratulates winning Panchayats
Article:
The Chief Minister of Uttarakhand, Trivendra Singh Rawat has congratulated the public representatives and villagers of three village Panchayats of the State that have been selected for Panchayati Raj Awards by the Union Government.

On Thursday, the Belpadav gram panchayat of Kotabagh block of Nainital district was awarded with the ‘Child friendly gram panchayat award’. Similarly the Nanaji Deshmukh Rashtriya Gaurav Gram Sabha award, 2020 was awarded to Kheldi village Panchayat of Bhadarabad block of Hardiwar district. The Kedarwala gram panchayat of Vikasnagar, Dehradun was selected for ‘Gram Panchayat development plan award, 2020.

On the occasion of the Rashtriya Panchayat Diwas-2020, the CM held telephonic conversation with many panchayat representatives on Friday and thanked them for supporting the government’s actions to prevent spread of COVID-19.

The Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the panchayat representatives of the country on the day and the CM Rawat listened the programme at his office. The minister for Panchayati raj, Arvind Pandey listened the address of PM with villagers at Village Panchayat Jainagar, Gadarpur in Udham Singh Nagar district while the additional secretary, Panchayati Raj H C Semwal and other senior officials of the department were present at Panchayati raj directorate in Dehradun to listen the PM’s address.

The Panchayati Raj department also released a documentary on the occasion which can be seen in the U tube channel of Department of Panchayati Raj.

In the documentary the department has included the quotes of union minister for Panchayati Raj, Narendra Singh Tomar, Uttarakhand cabinet minister Arvind Pandey, senior officials of department and many representatives of Panchayats.

Title: Locals consider boycotting Chinese products after lockdown
Article:
Considering the several unconfirmed allegations that China deliberately let novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) spread across the world, many shopkeepers and customers here have decided to boycott Chinese products after the lockdown ends in the State. Though the allegations are yet to be proved correct, they have influenced public opinion regarding Chinese products.

Ram Singh Kohli, a toy and gift store owner in Rajpur said, “More than 40 per cent of the gifts and toys are generally imported from China because the made in India products are costlier and the customers prefer cheaper products.

But considering China’s dubious role in the pandemic and its negative impact on the economy of several countries, I am not going to import any Chinese products.” After the COVID-19 pandemic, there is no point in buying Chinese products because the scare of the spread of the virus will remain for at least the next two years whether China is responsible for it or not, said the owner of a cosmetic store Ritu Sharma.

Many local customers have also emphasised on not purchasing Chinese products after the lockdown. Karnpur resident Ruchika Bhalla said that all the claims of China being responsible for the spread of COVID-19 appears true so the countries should not help their economy by buying Chinese products.

“I have always preferred to buy made in India products but now is the high time when everyone should stop buying any Chinese products, especially during the festivals like Diwali and Holi.

Everyone should buy Indian products and contribute to making our economy strong," added Bhalla. However, some shopkeepers and locals opined that people do not care about China or Indian products once they see the price. "Some people might claim currently that they will not buy Chinese products anymore but generally the customers prefer inexpensive products no matter where those are manufactured," said an E C Road shopkeeper Sanam Ali.

Title: Admin instructs to avoid gatherings during Ramzan
Article:
The Ranchi district administration as per the directives issued by Union Government has urged members from Muslim community to offer prayers and break their fast during the Holy month of Ramzan inside their homes instead of gathering at mosques or any other places in view of coronavirus outbreak. The Holy month of Ramzan set to begin from started on April 25 (Saturday).

Also as there is lockdown in place till May 3 across the country and restrictions have been imposed on celebrating festivals and offering prayers at public places by followers of all religions during this period.

Ranchi deputy commissioner (DC) Rai Mahimapat Ray in this connection has issued guidelines for Muslim community in view of coronavirus outbreak. As per the DC’s directions, religious heads and imminent personalities of the community have been informed that during Ramzan there will be no gathering for offering Namaz or breaking fast (Iftar).

Also it is observed that during this pious month members from Muslim community go for shopping, but the district administration guidelines state that at markets social distancing has to be made. The State government in this connection has also prepared a task force for successful implementation of directives. As per the directives, the minimum distance between two shops should be around fifteen feet and the it is duty of concerned shopkeepers to make a circle outside his shop at the distance of six feet so that social distancing is maintain.

The Ranchi district administration during the holy month has also banned plying of two wheelers and four wheelers, however during emergency situation the district administration has allowed plying of two wheelers and four wheelers carrying riders. Only one person is allowed on two wheelers while on four wheelers two persons including a driver is allowed. The district administration also states that wearing masks is mandatory while coming out of homes.

Moreover, complying with the directives of Union Government the Ranchi district administration too has started creating awareness about Suraksha Stores so that as many as grocery shops and general stores goes for norms as per Suraksha Stores.

Starting April 28, India will see the roll-out of as many as 10 lakh Suraksha Stores over 45 days, which will be designed as per the COVID-19 safety regulations laid by the Ministry of Consumer Affairs.

The Suraksha Store could be your nearby grocer or chemist, whose store will be managed by leading FMCG companies. Suraksha Store will have a poster at the entrance, so that the consumer is aware that she is entering a sanitised store along with social distancing norms.

Title: Observe social distancing during Ramazan: CM Rawat
Article:
The Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat has greeted the people of Uttarakhand, especially members of the Muslim community at the start of the month of Ramzan.

He said that this month is about brotherhood and mutual harmony. Rawat welcomed the appeal made by Muslim religious leaders asking their followers to offer prayers at home and maintain social distancing considering the risk of COVID-19.

He also appealed Muslims in Uttarakhand to follow such directions of their preachers. “COVID-19 has come as a threat for the whole humanity. We can defeat it with united effort. We must maintain social distancing ourselves and make others aware about its necessity too,” said the CM.

Title: Wearing masks made mandatory
Article: Wearing masks has been made compulsory for those going outside by Ranchi district administration. As per district administration guidelines those violating the norms will be penalized under Disaster Management Act 2005 and provisions under Indian Penal Code. The Ranchi district administration states that triple layer masks or home made three layer masks is permitted. Also the home made masks must be washed daily, sprayed with sanitizers. The Ranchi District administration also urges people to follow hygiene habits such as washing hands with soap or alcohol based sanitizers.

Title: Inbrief
Article:
UMU donates Rs 1.51 L to CM relief fund

Usha Martin University has contributed Rs 1.51 Lakh to the Chief Minister Relief Fund in the campaign against the Coronovirus epidemic. While giving this information, the Registrar of the University, Binod Kisapota said that the amount collected by the personnel and management of the university has been deposited in the Chief Minister's Relief Fund on 23 April through NEFT. University Vice Chancellor Prof. S. C. Garg said that the entire university is with the Central and State Governments in this fight against COVID-19. He conveyed his heartfelt gratitude to health workers, journalists, police administration and cleaning workers, with a message to strictly follow the lockdown rules. He also informed that all the teachers of the university are doing their duty in this difficult time, not only conducting regular online classes from their homes, but also guiding the students continuously.

Title: Admin to cancel home delivery passes for non-compliance
Article:
The permission granted to some enterprises for home delivery of products during the lockdown will be revoked in cases where the enterprises are not providing reports of daily thermal screening of delivery boys to the district administration.

Recently, the district administration had issued passes to selected restaurants for home delivery during the lockdown so that people who are capable of buying food but unable to cook can get the food easily. As a precautionary measure in the current crisis, the selected restaurants were asked to do a daily thermal screening of the staff including the delivery boys who pick up the food from eateries and send the reports to the district administration. However, many restaurants have not sent the reports to the administration for several days. Considering this, the district magistrate Ashish Kumar Shrivastava has decided to cancel the passes of such restaurants. Dehradun Chief Development Officer (CDO) Nitika Khandelwal informed that some eateries like Domino's have not submitted the report of delivery executives, especially from Swiggy and Zomato, therefore the passes issued to such restaurants for home delivery of food will be cancelled.

Title: Education Dept acting under pvt schools pressure: UAS
Article:
The Uttarakhand Abhibhavak Sangh (UAS) has alleged that the State education department is influenced by some private schools. The department takes decisions under the influence of some private schools, alleged the UAS. The Sangh questioned why the Uttarakhand Government was lagging behind when various State Governments have provided relaxation in school fees during the lockdown. "The education department recently declared that the parents who are capable of depositing the fee should submit it. Subsequently, the schools bombarded parents with several messages and emails reminding them to pay the fee that includes activity charges and lab charges besides tuition fee. Why is nothing being done against such schools?” questioned the UAS president Ram Kumar Singhal.

He further added that the government just heard the side of Principals Progressive Schools’ Association (PPSA) and did not consider how the parents will deposit the fee during such a crisis. According to the members of UAS, the parents have to buy new sets of books in the new session that costs thousands of rupees which is quite difficult to afford during the lockdown for several parents.

But the State Government is not giving any relaxation to parents, all it cares for is the private schools and their requirements, stated the members. "We will not accept it and we will not pay any kind of school fee during the lockdown. If other states can provide relaxation to the parents, our government can do it too. If needed, we will go to High Court too but will not submit to such irresponsible behaviour of the government and schools," stated Singhal.

Talking about the private schools asking for the fee including all the other charges, chief education officer Asha Rani Painuly said, "The parents must be looking at the old fee structure on schools' website as I recently received some similar complaints. Most of the schools have updated their website with a new fee structure." Painuly added that the schools have been instructed by the government to charge only tuition fees during the lockdown period. On being asked about the schools pressurising parents by sending emails and messages to deposit the fee, Painuly said that those who cannot submit the fee currently can reply to the school administration that they are incapable of paying the fee for now. The parents cannot be forced to pay the fee during the lockdown, stated Painuly.

Title: Rains to lash parts of State till April 28
Article:
Rainfall accompanied with thunderstorms, hailstorm and lighting is being forecast for Jharkhand till April 28. According to the Meteorological Centre, Ranchi scattered places of north west, central and south are likely to witness light to moderate showers on April 25. The Department has also issued a warning of gusty winds at a speed of 50- 60 Km per hour accompanied with thunderstorms, lighting and hailstorms are also being predicted in these areas. Fairly widespread heavy showers are being predicted in the north east on April 26 and in the central and southern parts on April 27. Gusty winds at a speed of 30-40 Km per hour with lighting are also on the forecast for the two days. On April 28, scattered rainfall is likely to occur across the State

“This is the pre monsoon season and rainfall is very normal for this time of the year. A trough at 1.5 Km above mean sea level runs from north Bihar to southwest Madhya Pradesh across Jharkhand and north Chhattisgarh is causing these showers,” said Deputy Director, MET Centre Ranchi, Abhishek Anand.

As per the MET Centre, Ranchi the maximum temperature might touch 40 degree Celsius only in places in the north western parts of Jharkhand

“With showers occurring in the north east, central and southern parts of Jharkhand, there will not much changes in the maximum temperature levels,” added the official.

As per the communiqué issued from April 25 to April 28, the maximum temperature in Ranchi and its surrounding areas is likely to remain around 30 to 32 degree Celsius.

Title: BJP activists distribute 100 ‘Modi diet kits’ among poor in Bokaro
Article:
In view of the crisis of livelihood arising due to the 40 day lockdown required to prevent global epidemic corona, senior BJP leader Vinay Kumar along with Zila Parishad member Bharat Yadav distributed Modi diet kits among the families of more than 100 daily laborers living in slums areas following maintaining the social distance. On this occasion, Bharat Yadav said that, without any government support, with the support and personal resources of his favored friends, even today, for the seventh day, the family of more than 100 daily laborers and till now a total of more than 700 families have been delivered of Modi Diet Kits.

In gratitude to outgoing MP Ravindra Kumar Pandey and other colleagues in the said work, Bharat Yadav said that today, as a panchayat representative on the day of National Panchayati Raj Day, in spite of my ill health, I also pledge that, in the hour of this crisis Zilla Parishad will try to do as much power as possible for the needy people of the area. But at such a time, DVC has completely failed to discharge its social corporate responsibility.

Yadav said that, despite being an elected panchayat representative of this region, despite the demand of distributing food and rescue materials to the needy in the villages falling under the ambit of Bokaro Thermal Establishment and necessary sanitization etc. for protection from Corona local officials were indifferent. But the formalities were completed by distributing only one hundred rupees worth of food items by arbitrarily flouting the social distance among some people by the local officials who came into action after talks with the high officials of the headquarters.

Whereas the Central Government, State Government and District Administration had called upon all PSUs to discharge their respective social obligations. Therefore, the apathy of the local management in this matter will be conveyed at all levels. Mithilesh Kumar Mahato appreciated the efforts of outgoing MP Ravindra Kumar Pandey and Zila Parishad member Bharat Yadav and called upon the able people to cooperate as much as possible. Apart from the above leaders, Anil Kumar Singh, Jagan Lohra, Anand Yadav, Vishal Kumar, Sumit Kumar, Shri Bhagwan Yadav, Mo. Azad etc. were present on this occasion.

Title: Fighting Covid-19: Admin plans doorstep delivery of sanitisers
Article:
East Singhbhum district administration has plans for door-step delivery of sanitisers for elderly and disabled in the city. The administration is already distributing free sanitisers for the poor across the district.

East Singhbhum district planning officer, Ajay Kumar who is monitoring the sanitizer distribution work in the district said that they have decided to announce a helpline number in which elderly and disabled can WhatsaAp or call to place order of the sanitizers (200 ml ) bottles which would be delivered at their doorstep through Indian Red Cross Society, Jamshedpur chapter volunteers.

“ We have come to know that several people are deprived of sanitisers due to lockdown. So it is aimed at facilitating provision of sanitizers for senior citizens and disabled who face problems in moving out of their house. They can place their order along with their address either through whatsapp or on the mobile phone and their order would be delivered within 24 hours at their home. However, this facility would only be for disabled and senior citizens who face problems in movement and are alone,” said Ajay Kumar.

Another official informed that COVID-19 awareness pamphlets have been distributed to people the door to door collection agents.

Continuous sanitization of market places, streets, housing complexes etc. with Hydrogen Peroxide and Sodium Hypochloride by ULV sprayer is being done.

Tata Steel Utilities and Infrastructure Services Ltd has carried mass Sanitization in the market areas on a daily basis ( Bistupur, Kadma, Sonari ( Kagalnagar and Gudri ), Sakchi, Baridih) with Mobile Jet Sprayer Machine is also being done. Along with sanitization drive, anti-larvae spraying of mosquitoes is also being done in the command area and the Bagan/Basti Area. Cold Fogging ( For mosquitoes ) is being done in the Command Area. Thermal Fogging is also being done in all areas as per schedule ( For Mosquitoes ).

Moreover, the company has installed full body sanitization system at its entry point for people/employees/ entering the premises.

Sanitisation of market places, streets, housing complexes etc are being carried with Hydrogen Peroxide and Sodium Hypochloride by ULV sprayer. Along with sanitization drive, anti-larvae spraying of mosquitoes is also being done in the command area.

The company is working to ensure that there is no interruption in basic civic amenities for the citizens of Jamshedpur during this period. It is continuing to provide the basic civic amenities like water and electricity.

The company is ensuring regular cleaning, fumigation and sanitization, garbage collection and disposal in Jamshedpur.

The customer complaints pertaining to city amenities are being handled through the existing helpline number and the online system. The online bill payment system, already in existence, , is being promoted aggressively.

Title: 1,11,568 stranded workers get monetary assistance
Article:
Chief Minister Hemant Soren today started transfer of Rs 1,000 through DBT to stranded Jharkhandi workers, who had registered in the CM Special Assistance App launched by the State Government. During the launch the CM said that today 1,11,568 labourers have been provided assistance of Rs 1,000 directly through DBT in their bank account. It is the goal of the government to help them financially, he said.

The CM said that due to coronavirus, the labourers of Jharkhand are trapped in large numbers in various states of the country. Right from the initial phase of lockdown, the State government had coordinated with the government officials of various states of the country to provide ration or food grains for the migrant labourers. In this episode, today, the assistance of Rs 1000 has been made available to the migrant labourers through the Chief Minister's Special Assistance Scheme mobile App.

He further said that till date, 2,47,0 25 migrant labourers of the State have registered for financial help through the Chief Minister's Special Assistance Mobile App. Various districts of Jharkhand have so far approved the registration of 2,10,464 labourers. He said that soon financial assistance will be made available to all the verified beneficiaries. He said that under the Internet banking system, the process of checking banks and accounts takes two to three days. The State government machinery is involved in carrying out these tasks with full commitment. As soon as the account verification of the beneficiaries is completed, the amount of financial support will be given immediately.

The CM said that the government has made provision to provide ration to those families, who do not have ration cards.

“The earlier process of providing ration has been changed today. Now the families who do not have ration card will be able to take ration directly from the nearest PDS dealer. Such families or people will no longer need to go elsewhere to get ration. The nearest dealers will provide ration by personally identifying such families, this will give them a lot of convenience,” he said.

The CM said that some disturbances and complaints have also been detected through MLAs, public representatives or media of the state regarding Chief Minister Didi Kitchen, Grain Distribution etc. The government is taking cognizance of all these disturbances and complaints.

Soren said that in Jharkhand, the State government is carrying out the work of providing relief material to the people in many ways with regard to social security since the initial time of Covid-19. The State government is absolutely serious that the people of the State do not have food problems during the lockdown period. It is the government's priority to ensure that no person falls asleep in the State.

The CM said that on Friday, Rs 8,30,15,000 have been given by the police officers and personnel of the State to fight the coronavirus and Rs 51,000 has been provided by the dentist tutors of RIMS, Ranchi. “I thank them wholeheartedly. We all believe that we will win this battle together,” he said.

On this occasion, Ministers Rameshwar Oraon, Satyanand Bhokta, Champai Soren, Banna Gupta, Chief Secretary Sukhdev Singh, Additional Chief Secretary Arun Kumar Singh, Principal Secretary to Chief Minister Rajiv Arun Ekka, Principal Secretary, AP Singh, Vinay Choubey, Director of IPRD Rajiv Lochan Bakshi, Press Adviser to CM Abhishek Prasad, Sr Pvt Secretary to CM Sunil Srivastava were present.

Title: Chouhan lauds cops’ role in corona crisis
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan in his message to the Police Officers-Employees said that in this hour of Corona crisis our police personnel are setting a new example of conscientiousness.

They are serving the public day and night by risking their lives. Along with strictly enforcing the lockdown, they are ensuring supply of essential commodities to the public and are helping them in every possible way.

"Our police personnel even in adverse circumstances are serving the disabled and elderly people, feeding the hungry by leaving their families behind and presenting a unique and commendable example of human service," he added.Chouhan said that some unfortunate incidents have made him very upset. He said that he becomes emotional when he remembers great warriors of Corona late Devendra Chandravanshi and Yashwant Pal. We will never forget their sacrifice. Chouhan said that these heroes laid down their lives in the line of duty. The government will give Rs. 50 lakh Samman Nidhi to each family, government job to a member of the family, extraordinary pension to the families (full salary till the date of retirement) and will honour them with Karmaveer medal.

The Chief Minister said that we will honour police personnel with Karmveer Medal for remarkable work. Chouhan said that our police personnel should not be under stress, do their duty carefully and keep the atmosphere calm and light.

Also be fully conscious of their safety. Use PPE kits while working in high risk areas. The Chief Minister told the police personnel that your life is very precious to us.

Title: 3 new cases in State, count reaches 59
Article:
Three fresh cases of coronavirus were reported from State on Friday, with two cases from Hindpiri and one case was reported from temple town Deoghar. With three new cases, the number of Covid 19 positive cases in State has gone up to 59.

State Health Secretary, Dr Nitin Madan Kulkarni said, “Three cases were reported on Friday. Two fresh was reported on Friday evening while one person was tested positive in Deoghar district the report of which was declared in the afternoon, with State corona patients figure going up to 59.”

The second corona patient was found in Deoghar on Friday. Deoghar Deputy Commissioner Nancy Sahay said that the patient hails from in Bhurkunda village of Sarwan block. The said person had come from Gujarat and was put on quarantine, where patient report was found to be positive during test. The patient had no primary symptoms related to corona, while his condition is said to be stable. Earlier, on April 20, a 17-year old youth was found positive with Covid 19. The youth had a travel history as he had come to Deoghar from Punjab via Delhi.

With the recovery of second Covid 19 patient in Santhal Pargana the entire region is panic as a week back the region was left with Covid 19 infection.

The recovery of two coronavirus cases in Santhal region is also cause on concern as both the patients are labourers having travel history. Sources said that a large chunk of population mostly tribals go to other states in search of work.

Meanwhile, the Deoghar district administration taking precautionary measures has deputed police personnel on every route and checkpost leading to the village. Also, the village has been sealed in view of the health safety. On Friday, 619 samples were collected for tests at four Covid 19 testing labs at RIMS Ranchi, MGM Jamshedpur, PMCH Dhanbad and Itki Arogyashala, Itki, Ranchi. Out of collected samples 363 samples were found to be tested, with 360 samples tested as negative while three cases was detected as positive.

Moreover, the increase of corona patient is cause of concern for state as on Friday out of 57 patients who were tested positive people below the age group of 50 was 45, while those who are above the age group of 51 the number is 12. Out of 13 elderly person three persons have died while two persons who are above 50 years have recovered. District wise Ranchi has 35 Covid 19 case with active case figures as 28.

Moreover, in other development a 32-year-old RPF jawan deployed at Ghatshila in East Singhbhum district has tested positive for Covid-19 at Kharagpur.

East Singhbhum deputy commissioner Ravi Shankar Shukla along with a health team went to Ghatshila. He was informed by the South Eastern Railway today about the RPF jawan from Ghatshila barrack being positive.

Two of the RPF personnel deputed at Ghatshila barrack had been part of a RPF contingent which had gone to Delhi and had returned via Kharagpur to Ghatshila earlier this month and had been kept under quarantine at the RPF barrack.

However, after one of their personnel reports turned positive in Balasore the railway authorities called back the two RPF personnel to Kharagpur for Covid-19 testing wherein one of the personnel reports turned positive while the other one is negative.

Title: CM advises farmers to maintain social distancing at procurement centres
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has that the Government has started procuring wheat and other Rabi crops at support price from the farmers at a wide scale.

Farmers should reach the procurement centers to sell their crops at the procurement centers on fixed date only on getting informed through SMS. Use masks, sanitiser, frequent washing of hands and follow full social distancing, he added.

Chouhan further mentioned that in this time of Corona crisis, a facility has been provided to the farmers by the Government to sell crop through Souda Patrak (Sale Letter) directly to the traders.

Farmers can sell produce to the registered traders at their home itself or on private centers through Souda Patrak.

Chouhan told the farmers that if they get correct price for their produce, then only they should give their consent on the Souda Patrak. You have the security cover of the support price.

Besides,the Chief Minister urged the farmers to follow total lockdown and be vigilant towards their health.

Use Gamchha if mask is not available. Sell Rabi crops by maintaining sufficient distance at the procurement centers.

Title: AISECT extending services to help fight financial crisis
Article:
During the lockdown, Banking kiosks are operated by AISECT, extending their services to the citizens to help them with financial crisis.

The kiosks are open to the public from 7 am to 7 pm. Direct benefit transfer money of various Government schemes has also come into the Jan Dhan accounts operated under it and people can transact money easily.

In addition to the kiosks, AISECT is also making efforts to provide direct financial services to households in these difficult times, so that people will have least trouble and avoid coronavirus to get maximum financial service benefits. In this, a vehicle has been converted into a customer service point, providing financial services to homes and street neighborhoods. In addition to providing financial services, banking kiosks are following and following the Government's instructions with special care, in which sanitisation and social distancing are special. Apart from this, various measures are being taken to avoid corona virus infection at the kiosks, including the use of masks and gloves, sanitisation of kiosk points and machines, disinfection, maintaining a minimum distance of 1 meters.

There are around 3000 banking kiosks of AISECT across the country.

Along with this, various banking kiosks of AISECT are also cooperating in relief work under which ration and food items are being distributed to the needy people.

It is to be noted that financial services come in the list of essential services of the Government. Due to this, banking kiosks operated by AISECT are also running financial services in various rural, semi-rural and urban areas of the city.

Title: Man with fake pistol caught impersonating cop in uniform
Article:
The police arrested a man impersonating a police sub inspector moving around in the market with a fake pistol. The accused was taking advantage of the lockdown and was patrolling in Jwalapur and other areas. The police constable on duty found his actions suspicious on noticing him. When questioned in the police station, the accused confessed to being an impersonator.

Police circle officer (City) Abhay Singh said that local resident Jaindra Kumar bought khaki dress from the market and was roaming around on a bike with a fake pistol. He was planning to take advantage of the lockdown.

A native of Prayagraj in Uttar Pradesh, Kumar was seen in Jwalapur in the last two days. When the local constable asked him about his posting, Kumar said that he is posted in Dehradun. This raised suspicion after which he was brought to the police station where he confessed his crime during questioning. An FIR has been booked against him under section 419 of the IPC, added Singh.

Title: 5 drown in Masanjor dam as boat capsizes
Article:
In a tragic incident five members of a family from Jitpur village in Dumka district, drowned in Masanjor dam, 25 km from Dumka on Thursday evening after their boat capsized. One man swam out after winds and tide turned the boat turtle.

Six members of a family including two women were returning from Bansjora village to Kathaliya village, when the incident occurred. One village head Shivdhan Murmu swam out of the dam. The Masalia police, which falls under the jurisdiction of Dumka district, have registered accidental death case in the connection.

One person was swam to safety, but five others went missing after a boat capsized in the Masanjor dam in Dumka, said Dy SP Santosh Kumar said.

Later on Friday afternoon bodies of four out of the five persons were found, the Dy SP said, adding that search was underway for the fifth victim.

The victims who were found to be identified as Muqtar Murmu, Pakku Marandi and Julamas Hembram (1-year- old), he said.

Police earlier registered a case against the boat operator for violating lockdown norms and not taking any precautions or providing life jackets to those on the boat.

The five have been identified as Muqtar Murmu (50), Sukul Tudu (40), Arsu Marandi (35) wife of Sukul Tudu, Piku Marandi (30) and one year old kid Julamas Hembram, two bodies of Sukul Tudu and his wife Arsu Marandi are still missing.

The one who swam to safety has been identified as Shivdhan Murmu (42). After the boat capsized, Masalia police and Fire Brigade teams were engaged to rescue five members of the family. But all five, remained untraceable.

A case under IPC sections 304 (A) (rash and negligent act causing death), 188 (disobedience to order lawfully promulgated by a public servant) was registered against the boat operator (name not disclosed).

The operator violated prohibitory orders which restrict movement of five or more persons during lockdown to contain coronavirus, and did not provide life jackets, a police official said, adding further probe was on.

Title: Transgender woman sets example, offers food to needy in Covid crisis
Article:
Meet Rajkumari, a transgender woman, who has set an example amid the COVID-19 crisis by helping out the needy in Bokaro.

Amidst, nationwide lockdown to curtail the spread of the coronavirus Rajkumari is providing free packages of food to the needy and those living in slums.

On Friday she distributed 150 free food kits – consisting of rice, flour, oil, tea leaves, and sugar other things among the daily wage earners, residents of slum areas and other needy people in Ritudih under Marafari police station at Bokaro Steel City.

During the distribution of the food kits, she also maintained the social distancing norms. “We pray to almighty that our country become free from coronavirus infection very soon,” she said.

“We use to manage our home by demanding from society, but now-a-days people are reeling under a difficult situation. In such a situation, it’s our duty to give return back the society as much as possible,” said Rankumari adding, “it’s my duty to share those things with the poor.”

I would like to urge from the affluent persons to come forward and help the needy in this adverse situation, she said.

Rajkumari, is one of them who dedicated her life for others and taking care of discarded children. Not only that, but she also arranged the marriage of those three girls whom she had found from bushes as an infant and adopted till puberty and given them a complete social dignity.

She dedicated her life to taking care of discarded children along with a blind couple since 1984. Now those couples (blind) are not alive but the children have grown up and living a happy life with their families.

Her complete dedication towards the philanthropic work teaches us a lesson by which she spreading the fragrance of love, sympathy and joy in the society. Playing the role of a mother for those children who were discarded by their own parents since their birth Rajkumari is still struggling for a better future. Presently she has five girls and two boys.

Out of seven, six of them got married; Rajkumari arranged their marriages (five girls and one boy) whom she had found from bushes as an infant. The youngest son Sambhu is yet to get married, she said.

Kaushallya, Rinku, Saraswati, Rashema and Munni are those girls who are now happily living along with their husbands and children at Nawada, Bokaro and Gopalganj respectively.

Expressing happiness she said, now, I am a grandmother (‘nani’) of thirteen children including eleven girls and two boys. Kaushallya has three girl children, Rinku having two girls and one boy child, Saraswati has two girl children, Reshma has two girls and one male child while my elder son has two girl children, she said.

“One more member will join our family very shortly. My youngest daughter with a hope, the birth is scheduled within this week,” she added with a smile on her face.

On the money that she earns through the dance during rituals at childbirth and marriage ceremony in the city, she has adopted many other children too.

Besides these seven Upendra, Mantu, Rameshwar, Shubham, Jitendra, Amresh are few of them, now they are well settled at other cities.

Title: Muslim inmates of quarantine centres can keep Roza: DC
Article:
Muslim inmates of institutional quarantine centres in Palamu if they so desire and have no health problem can keep Roza that begins from Saturday, April 25.

DC Palamu Shantanu Kumar Agrahari said, “I understand Muslim inmates undergoing institutional quarantine may like to keep roza and here administration has no problem at all. They are free to keep it. We will provide them all help.”

Agrahari said, “Everyone will agree that proper health and good physique in institutional quarantine is need of the day. No one can afford to give it a miss. If one is all in good health then one is free to practice this tool of faith.” He said, “We will find out as to how many of this faith are undergoing institutional quarantine and how many desire to have it and accordingly we will direct centres’ incharge to arrange their Sehri and Iftaar without any problem. Sehri and Iftaar will be surely arranged and no one should have any worry on this account.”

SP Palamu Ajay Linda said faithful are free to have this observance of faith but with strict adherence to social distancing and other protocol of lock down like remaining confined to the centre and keeping and doing hand wash as far as possible. Linda said administration goads everyone to follow guidelines of MHA for quarantine and there should not be any laxity on the part of its doers.

SDPO Sadar Sandip Kumar Gupta said, “ Under order of SP Linda we have found that a total of 29 Muslim inmates of 8 governmental quarantine centres in his police sub division have expressed their desire to keep roza for the days they will be at the centre before being asked by authorities to undergo home quarantine as well.”

Gupta said the 8 governmental quarantine centres are one each at Nawajaipur, Town thana, Satbarwa, Chainpur, Paton, Parwa, Sadar, Ramgarh where etc. Gupta said as on today April 24 there is no Muslim inmate at centres at Nawajaipur, Ramgarh, Chainpur & at Paton.

Gupta said our SP Linda has asked all officers in charge to ensure that no inmate of any governmental quarantine centre be he of any faith face any problem. He said drone was flown at Satbarwa today to keep an eye on anyone even loitering in mohalla’s alley too to send him/ her indoors.

Gupta said he met a cross section of people drawn from both the communities at Satbarwa who said they are following lock down properly.

Title: PM rings city BJP leader, seeks information about work being done by party workers
Article:
Amid ongoing lockdown over fear of corona, Prime Minister Narendra Modi made a telephone call to city-based BJP senior leader and his old friend Mahesh Chandra Sharma on Friday afternoon and sought information about his health and wellbeing.

The Prime Minister spoke to Sharma for about three minutes. Modi took information about his health asked about people’s reaction over the ongoing lockdown. He also sought information over BJP workers engaged in service for general public.

Sharma informed the PM due to the lockdown people are finding difficult as employment has sit. However, the party leader assured PM that public stands firmly with him.

The people of Jamshedpur have unwavering trust and affection towards him. He told that BJP workers are also constantly engaged in service work to help the poor and the needy.

Mahesh Chandra Sharma, being the president of Rajasthan Brahman Sangh has turned Jugasalai Rishi Bhavan for use as a quarantine center. The centre currently holds 37 people. Prime Minister lauded efforts of Mahesh Chandra Sharma.

He was appreciated and noted and wished good health to him. PM said in the course of the conversation that the present difficulty will help us in protecting from troubles.

In comparison, India has tried its best so far. Many developed countries of the world are also praising India's efforts.

Reacting over the gesture of Modi, BJP District President Dinesh Kumar expressed happiness.

He said that it is a pleasant feeling that PM is calling party workers of the city.

Title: Burial in Palamu helps humanity shine in extreme distress
Article:
Humanity shone most brightly at village Gopalganj in Palamu district where on April 23 evening, a youth who died in institutional quarantine without any health issue or symptom at all on Wednesday April 22 night was given a silent but graceful burial with no whisper of any protest or suspicion.

Civil surgeon John F Kennedy described this youth’s health card as asymptomatic and all healthy with no remote sign or symptom of any morbidity.

SDPO, Lesliganj, Anup Baraik, said, “The youth was buried with body bag. It was not opened at all. His family members cooperated with us. The body in bag was straight taken down to the grave yard.”

Baraik said, “Some family members wanted thebody in bag to be given to them but we knew their sentiments, emotions and tremendous grief over the death of the youth would made them ignore health safeguards and so we did a hard persuasion and this family agreed to our point which was body in bag at graveyard not at home.”

Baraik said the burial was done quite silently and without any protest or resistance. The village mourned but not erupted in any anger suspicion or doubt unlike other places where cremation or burial is now a challenging task.

However Baraik said some in the Muslim community wanted last bath for the dead which is a very important post death ritual in Islam but here permission for last bath would have meant opening of the body bag which was not beneficial from health point to any one and so here again police did hard job and got the family ready to skip this rite more for the peace of the dead and the family did accordingly.

SP Ajay Linda said police are waiting for the post mortem report. The post mortem has been done by a board of 3 doctors.

Sources said the family has expressed its utmost suspicion over the death of the youth in the governmental quarantine centre citing allegations that this youth was given a separate room, the window from where it is said he hanged himself to death is very low in height, there is scratch on his one hand only, a woman with grams went to his room on Wednesday evening and finally police found this body in bed not hanging then who the inmate is to remove and place this body in bed.

SP Palamu Ajay Linda said, “Police are investigating this case from all angles. This inmate lived single in that centre. He had wounds on his left wrist only. There was a ball pen with its nib broken. “

Linda said a woman who is the inmate of this centre did go to his room with gram only to find him dead there.

SP agreed the body was found in bed when police reached there but he added this could be when some good samaritans tried hard to untie the hanging knots with the hope the fellow may resuscitate to life.

Linda said call details of this youth had found him ‘only talking on phone’ for 4 days that he spent at this centre from day one April 18 to day end April 22.

Title: Huge cache of explosives recovered at Giridih
Article:
A huge quantity of liquid and dry explosive materials, including gelatin and detonators were recovered from Arwara village under Bhelwaghati police station in Giridih during a search operation being conducted by the security forces on Thursday, said ASP Deepak Kumar here on Friday.

The consignment of explosive was supposed to be kept under a culvert to be delivered to the Maoists for making bombs.

"A total of 1085 gelatin rods along with 410 detonators have been recovered under a culvert on Jamui-Giridih road on Thursday during a search operation," said Giridih ASP Deepak Kumar.

A search operation was launched on Thursday after the SP got a tip-off that a huge volume of explosives was being transferred in the area. "As we got information that a consignment of explosives is to be delivered to the Maoists in the area, we immediately got alerted and rushed to the spot," said Kumar. "As soon as we reached there about five to six suspected persons present at the spot, ran away taking the advantage of darkness in the nearby jungles," Kumar added.

Title: Helping Hands carries out milk drive in city, reaches out to poor
Article:
Due to the lockdown, the food crisis is increasing among poor and needy families. The youngsters of the city have pulled up their socks and are reaching out to the poor families.

A Milk Drive is being carried out in the city by youth groups Bhopal Helping Hands and Ansh Happiness Society for the small children. Here on Friday, as many as 400 milk packets were distributed among poor and needy families. The volunteers of the groups have diatributed milk packets in Sanjay Nagar, Khanugaon and Balveer Nagar. While everyone is in their homes during lockdown, the poor and needy section of the society is suffering. Looking at this, the youngsters of the city have pulled up their socks to help them.As the COVID-19 has a serious outbreak in the country, 21 day lockdown was announced by Government. But, in all this, the most suffered section is poor and needy people. To help them, youngsters of the city are distributing food packets and ration to the needy people.

But, now they have also begun the Milk Drive for children till or under 5 years. Under another initiative of distribution of food packets, 200 food packets were distributed among the needy and poor families. The packets were especially distributed among daily wagers.

Title: Will bring back stranded MP labourers: Chouhan
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has said that the State Government will bring back the labourers of Madhya Pradesh stranded in other States due to the lockdown. Necessary action will be taken in this connection.

Chouhan also discussed the matter in detail with the Chief Ministers of Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Gujarat and Maharashtra labourers. They assured full cooperation.

The Chief Minister said that family members of the labourers stranded in other States will be permitted to go from Madhya Pradesh to bring them back.

Simultaneously, labourers from other States stranded in Madhya Pradesh will also be permitted to go back to their States. For this, they will be able to use their own means or those provided by their State Governments. He told that the workers stranded within Madhya Pradesh in the districts will be able to travel back to their districts. Instructions are being issued to the officials in this connection.

Chief Minister Chouhan informed that the safe return of workers will be ensured strictly observing social distancing. Elaborate arrangements will be made for screening and testing of labourers returning home at the borders of districts.

Movement from containment area and Indore district restricted

No labourers will be allowed to move from the infected areas of the State and from Indore district. The Chief Minister directed the officials concerned to complete all arrangements in this regard so that the labourers do not face any problem.

Title: Baghel urges Centre to extend rice procurement limit under central pool
Article:
Baghel writes letter to Union Food Minister Ramvilas Paswan and requests extension of procurement limit from 24 LMT to 31.11 LMT of rice for central pool

Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Friday requested Union food and consumer welfare minister Ramvilas Paswan to permit to raise the rice procurement limit for the Food Corporation of India (FCI) in the current kharif marketing year from 24 lakh MT to 31.11 lakh MT.

In a letter to Paswan, the CM said that the current circumstances due to Covid-19 pandemic have created increased requirement of rice in the other states as well.

“Due to which, the FCI had to transport food grains to other states in April 2020. This has created an empty space in the warehouses of the FCI in Chhattisgarh, He said.

For the prevention of Covid-19 pandemic, the state government is making consistent efforts in an integrated manner with awareness and compassion, Baghel said in the letter.

“To prevent the spread of Covid-19 infection, the lockdown has been in effect in Chhattisgarh as well, and it is being implemented without interruptions, as per the guidelines. The Centre’s Pradhan Mantri Gareeb Kalyan Ann Yojana is also being implemented effectively, which has brought great relief to people of the state,” he said.

“In view of the current circumstances, I would like to draw your attention towards the fact that in Chhattisgarh, a total 83.67 lakh tons of paddy was procured from 18.34 lakh farmers in 2019-20.

“Paddy procurement and collection of custom milling rice is done in the state as per the MoU signed between the Chhattisgarh government and the Union food and public distribution department, the chief minister said.

The Section 18 of the MoU signed between the Chhattisgarh government and Union food and public distribution department includes the provision that states the FCI should procure all the surplus rice, he said.

In a letter, the Union public distribution department had given permission to procure 24 lakh tons of Usna rice in kharif marketing year 2019-20 under central pool of the FCI.

In KMY 2019-20, out of the 56.51 lakh MT of rice produced from the 83.67 lakh tons of paddy procured in Chhattisgarh, the state government will procure 25.40 lakh MT of rice for PDS requirement of the state (Central pool 15.48 lakh metric ton, State Pool 9.92 lakh metric ton) and remaining 31.11 metric tons of rice will be surplus, the CM said in his letter.

Out of which the Centre will permit FCI to procure 24 lakh MT of rice, which will redress only 73.30 lakh MT of the procured rice, whereas nearly 10.47 lakh metric tons of paddy (proportionate to 7.11 lakh metric tons of rice) will remain unaddressed, he said.

Under the circumstances created due to Covid-19 pandemic and the lockdown will have long-term adverse effect on the economy of the nation as well as the states, Bgahel said.

“In this situation, if the surplus rice in Chhattisgarh is not redressed properly, the state may incur losses worth nearly Rs 1500 crore, which will further adversely impact economic development of the state in this already critical situation.”

Title: Chhattisgarh Power Company adjudged third in country
Article:
The central electricity authority (CEA) on Friday placed the Chhattisgarh state power company in the third position in the state-sector wise category of performance of thermal power stations across the country, a statement said.

In a statement, the power generation company’s managing director NK Bijora said the CEA has placed the power company in third position.

The Dr Shyama Prasad Mukherjee thermal power station (DSPMTPS), Korba has also been placed in the eighth position in the country, he said.

Welcoming the dual achievement as a proud moment for the state and extending greetings to the power generation team’s official and staff, chairman of the power company Subrat Sahoo urged them to retain the high quality of functioning so that the state continues to hold on to the top position in power generation.

Highlighting the achievement, Bijora said: “In the country, under the 34 state sectors, a large number of thermal power plants are functional. Chhattisgarh has one of the oldest thermal power stations in the country but maintains the high plant load factor (PFL) of 67.32 percent.

He further said that DSPMTPS also found a place in the top ten power stations among the central, state and private power sectors. The power plant has two units of 250 MW, with a total capacity of 500 MW.

Title: C’garh sends 75 buses to Kota for bringing stranded students
Article:
In a significant relief for students stranded Rajasthan’s Kota district, the Chhattisgarh government on Friday sent 75 buses to the coaching hub to bring back more than 1,500 students hailing from different districts across the state.

“The buses are being sent to bring back children who are stuck in Kota. All the necessary arrangements have been made to bring them back safely,” Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel said in a statement.

Notable, Kota is a hub of coaching institutes for India’s premier entrance exams for medical and engineering colleges. More than 30 lakh people reside in the city, out of which a major chunk is students who come to prepare for the entrance exams.

Recently, Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh brought back the stranded students from their states from Kota even as the lockdown continues and taking a cue from the other states, the Chhattisgarh chief minister too sought special permission from Union home minister Amit Shah by calling him on Thursday.

Title: Seven arrested for alleged Naxal links
Article:
The Chhattisgarh police on Friday claimed to have busted an alleged Maoist urban support network, with the arrest of seven people, including three construction contractors, from separate places.

While two persons, identified as Tapas Palit and Dayashankar Mishra were arrested last month, five others were held recently by the Kanker district police , inspector general of police (Bastar range) Sundarraj P said.

On March 24 this year, police had intercepted Palit ,a construction contractor while he was allegedly transporting a huge consignment of shoes, fabrics and walkie-talkie sets, meant for Maoist rebels, in his SUV, from the Siksod police station area of Kanker district, he said.

Palit, during interrogation, revealed about the Maoist courier network ,which was supplying various materials and cash to the Maoists rebels from the last two years in the area, he said.

Later, another person, identified as Dayashankar Mishra, who was associated with him, was also arrested from Rajandgaon district, the police officials said.

For an extensive probe into the matter, a Special Investigation Team (SIT) of the Kanker police led by additional superintendent of police Kirtan Rathore was then constituted, Sundarraj P said.

The SIT recently arrested five more people—Ajay Jain (45), Komal Prasad Verma, both Rajnandgaon based contractors, Rohit Nag (33) of Koyalibeda in Kanker, Sushil Sharma (50) of Uttar Pradesh and Suresh Sharnagat (28) of Madhya Pradesh—in this connection, the Bastar range police chief said.

As per preliminary investigation, two contractors—Nishant Jain of Bilaspur and Varun Jain of Rajnandgaon—who run the Landmark Engineer Company and Landmark Royal Engineer Company respectively, were allotted road construction works under Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojna (PMGSY) in Antagarh, Amabeda, Siksod, Koyalibeda and other Maoist -hit areas of Kanker district, the IGP said.

The two firms then authorized to carry out the construction works to Ajay Jain, Komal Prasad Verma and Palit, who are said to be partners in a company deals in construction work, he said.

The three allegedly established communication with Maoist rebels and had been supplying shoes, Maoist uniforms, walkie-talkie sets and other materials along with cash to them for the last two years, he said adding that the remaining arrested persons are their accomplices.

The involvement of several other people in the offence is being probed, he added.

According to police, Maoists suffered a huge blow with these arrests as the ongoing lockdown has already paralyzed their supply chain.

Title: Covid-19 well under control in state, 83% recovery rate: Singhdeo
Article:
The contagious coronavirus is well under control in the state until now with 30 out of the 36 Covid-19 stricken people having recovered from the pathogen, the recovery rate in the state has climbed to 83.3%, said state health minister.

The curve for the positive cases too has flattened as no new case has been reported in the last couple of days, said health minister TS Singhdeo on Friday.

In a Tweet, Singhdeo thanked the healthcare care professionals of the state for the achievement and wished speedy recovery of the rest six patients being treated at the AIIMS, Raipur.

“At present only six active patients are being treated at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Raipur and all of whom are linked to the Katghora hotspot.

“The town of Katghora had until now contributed exactly 75% or 27 out of the 36 people stricken by the Covid-19 pathogen in the state,” Singhdeo said in his tweet.

Title: C’garh demands health kits, apparatuses from Centre
Article:
Chhattisgarh on Friday demanded 50,000 N-95 masks, 20,000 VTM (viral transport media) kits and 250 ventilators from the Union health ministry.

State health minister TS Singhdeo while participating in a meeting called by Union health minister Dr Harshvardhan via video conference, requested him to fix Chhattisgarh’s quota in the triple-layer masks being prepared by the CRPF.

Sharing the requirements of the state for fighting the Covid-19 pandemic, Singhdeo demanded 50,000 N-95 masks, 20,000 VTM (viral transport media) kits and 250 ventilators.

Singhdeo also shared the preparedness of Chhattisgarh in dealing with Covid-19 and informed the Union health minister that at present the state already has 5,666 beds ready for coronavirus patients in different hospitals.

“In different ICUs and semi-ICUs, Chhattisgarh has 622 ventilators along with 300 child ventilators. The state has a stock of 8.20 lakh hydroxychloroquine tablets for dealing with Covid-19 pandemic.

“In addition, private-run hospitals have also been identified for dealing with any emergency situation. In case the situation deteriorates, then hostels with attached toilets have also been identified,” Singhdeo said..

Through pool testing and RD Kit surveillance, the state is trying to identify coronavirus positive patients from among the suspected individuals, he said.

“Until now, samples of 10,346 people have been collected, out of which 9,206 people have tested negative for coronavirus while 1,104 samples are under test.

“In Chhattisgarh, 36 positive cases of Covid-19 were reported, out of which 30 were successfully treated and discharged from the hospital while six are under treatment,” Singhdeo told the Union minister.

Title: Monitoring done by ‘live’ videography with help of ‘CCTV surveillance’
Article:
Special monitoring is done from the control room by ‘live’ videography with the help of ‘CCTV surveillance’ vehicle in the containment areas.

In order to strictly follow the lockdown, 3 CCTV surveillance vehicles in the city are continuously monitoring day and night in the containment areas under north and south Bhopal,

cameras are been moved in CCTV surveillance vehicles and the person found walking outside or sitting outside the houses are instructed that recording is been done and action will be taken against them. After spotting the camera in many areas, people move inside the houses on their own making the job easier for police.By using the Public Announcement (PA) system, people are advised to go inside their houses in the containment area by these vehicles.The operation of the surveillance vehicle is seen live in the control room CCTV surveillance, which also shows people violating the lockdown and on the spot they are advised and those resisting face action which is been done by the police stations on the field making the system functioning in a coordinated manner.

Apart from this, live videography with video cameras is being monitored of these containment areas, in which the containment areas of Jehangirabad and Jinsi are monitored live from CCTV surveillance control room which could help in checking the spread of Coronavirus with strictness.

The results are good as it has helped the police to monitor in a better and efficient way and require less efforts to vigil large areas under containment.

Title: 60-year-old man dies after he was attacked by miscreant over dispute
Article:
A 60-year-old man died after he was attacked by miscreant over a dispute at Neelbad in the afternoon on Friday; Ratibad police have started investigated.

Incharge of Ratibad police station GP Tripathi said that no visible injury marks were found over the body and in the short post mortem report it was found that the deceased died of cardiac arrest after his blood pressure shot enormously high.

In the investigation it was found that the deceased used to work with a private contractor and was at home during the lockdown and in the afternoon at around 12. 30 he was smoking (weed) with the accused Ram Kishore Ahirwar during which the two had a heated argument in an inebriated state and later they scuffled in

which the deceased who was fragile fail to face the deceased and fell over ground and later when he was taken to hospital he was declared dead.

Bruises marks were found over the body and which were also found over the body of the accused. Tripathi denied of any smashing of head by stone of deceased.

Body was sent for the post mortem after the preliminary investigation.

The police have registered a case under section 174 of the CrPC and have started further investigation.

Police said that accused would be charged with case of murder if it is found in the investigation and the detailed post mortem is awaited which could help in the investigation.

The details of the accused has to be investigated, said police.

Title: 23-yr-old woman commits suicide by hanging from ceiling at Kajlikheda
Article:
A 23-year old married woman committed suicide by hanging with the ceiling at Kajlikheda under Kolar police station late in the night on Thursday; reason remained unknown and police have started investigation.

According to the police, Vinita Solanki was found hanging and was rushed to a nearby hospital where she was declared dead.Police said that the deceased was housewife and married to Ramkrishan Solanki a year ago.

The family members were not aware of any kind of fight or dispute of Vinita with her husband or with any family member and in the investigation no suicide note has been recovered.After the preliminary investigation the body was sent for the post mortem. The police have registered a case under section 174 of the CrPC and have started further investigation.The statements of family members are yet to be recorded and which would help in revealing the reason behind the suicide.

Meanwhile, a 17-year-old girl died after she fell in a well near her house in Nariyalkheda under Gautam Nagar police station area; deceased went to fill water and fell accidentally on Thursday.

Police said that the deceased Shivani Singh was found drowned in a well near her house.In the initial investigation police found that the deceased had gone to fill water and while filling water she fell inside the well.

The police have registered a case under section 174 of the CrPC and started further investigation.The deceased was class 10 student and was a meritorious student.

Title: Five test +ve in Ashoka Garden of Old City
Article:
Amidst rapid increase in Coronavirus infections in the State capital, in a major goof up, authorities allegedly allowed quarantined eight members of two families to go home without waiting for their test reports.

Later, the next day when their tests reports were received and it was found that five of them were positive, the administration in a tizzy searched for the positive members of the family. The incident was reported from Nawab Colony in Ashoka Garden area of Old city Bhopal.Two families reside in a rented premise in Nawab Colony and the owner of the building, a school van driver, had tested positive for covid19. The man initially had reported cough-cold and was admitted to Shakir Ali hospital and later was shifted to government Hamidia hospital where the physicians advised covid19 test.

After the man tested positive, he was referred to Chirayu hospital and those living in his building were quarantined in a government facility.The eight members of these two families were sent back home on Wednesday by the officials at the quarantine facility and on Thursday they received phone calls that they have been tested positive for covid19.

Then these persons were admitted to Chirayu hospital. These include a media person whose family of five has been tested positive including a five-year-old daughter.These families had alleged that they were returned to home simply by officers at the quarantine facility as they did not exhibit any suspected symptoms.Talking to The Pioneer, Chief Medical and Health Officer Bhopal Dr Prabhakar Tiwari claimed that persons concerned were not released causally from quarantine and were advised to remain in home quarantine. He claimed that this was done due to limited space available in the quarantine facility.

The physician also rejected reports that over 350 corona virus samples have failed and the persons concerned haven’t been informed about this. We are continuously carrying out tests in the city, Dr Tiwari added.

The number of fresh positive cases were 37 on Friday including two who had died in Bhopal. The total positive cases rose to 747 in the city by Friday including nine deaths.

Overall 78 have recovered from the disease in the city and 75 were expected to be discharged from two different hospitals on Friday late evening.

Title: Club Literati in city brings William Shakespeare back through Virtually Yours
Article:
Bringing together literature enthusiasts from different fields, Club Literati on Thursday brought William Shakespeare back to life through Virtually Yours. The event is being marked the inauguration of the four day online festival Virtually Yours Shakespeare, celebrating the birth anniversary of the legendary laureate on April 23.

On Friday, the online competition marked the second day. On Friday, event Bard on the Podcast was held. It was held in two categories, first was Shakespearean Sonnets and second was Self-composed Sonnets. In this competition the participants presented sonnets by Shakespeare and the self composed sonnets as well.

On Saturday, ‘The Globe Theatre’ will be held. It will bee held in two categories – Soliloquies and Monologues. On Sunday, other unique competitions like ‘Bard Goes Bollywood’ – Recasting Shakespeare’s famous plays with Bollywood artists and ‘A Wish for William’ Drawing competition will be held.This unique virtual festival has been curated observing the present scenario across the world i.e. the lockdown due to Coronavirus.

William Shakespeare is considered as one of the greatest playwrights ever of English Literature. His plays, along with his collection of sonnets, contain unparalleled poetic beauty and his knowledge is hugely diverse.

Further, in every play of Shakespeare is related to history in some way or the other. His writings are considered as the best scripts of all times to be staged.Throughout the 20th and 21st centuries, Shakespeare's works have been continually adapted and rediscovered by new movements in scholarship and performance.

Title: Archdiocese starts online counselling services
Article:
Archdiocese of Bhopal activated ASHADEEP Counselling centre which was inaugurated in February 2020.

Archbishop Leo Cornelio said that the novel corona virus (COVID-19) pandemic is a situation that is affecting people of all ages specially children physically as well as psychologically.

The pandemic has caused strong feelings such as sadness, fear, anxiety, helplessness, uncertainty, loss of interest and hopelessness he said to the reporters.

Sitting at home completely without work,without outing and without socialising is a matter of concern for people today. Mostly elderly people are depressed in this lockdown as their normal schedule is disturbed. Woman is the emotional pillar of the family. And they are feeling suffocated totally at home. They are not finding any channel to expel out out their frustration. Bread earners of the family are living in anxiety and fear today. They are worried to feed their family during and after lockdown. Depression, anxiety and boredom he said.To provide support and address mental health concerns of children and adult during and after COVID-19, Archdiocese of Bhopal has launched a new venture of online 'Counselling Services for all’ through ASHADEEP, a centre for Wholeness free of cost through its trained counselors.Fr Maria Stephen, the PRO said that ASHADEEP is a group of Psychologists and clinical psychologists to provide mental fitness to people by empowering their minds and by providing emotional wellness. The people wishing to seek guidance can get in touch with counselors on whatsapp, mobile number and email address provided are:- 1.

Dr Reena Rajput (psychovisionbpl@gmail.com), mobile- 09425080444 (Wednesday and Friday 9 am to 11 am), 2. Dr Vinai Mishra (drvinaymishra@rediffmail.com), mobile- 9425648065 (Daily 9 am to 10 am), 3. Dr Priya Sonpar (priyasonpar@gmsil.com), mobile- 9425356605 (Daily 10 am to 12 pm), 4. Gerard Pereira (gerryapereira@gmail.com), mobile- 9826726967 (Daily 8 am to 8 pm), 5. Rhea Pereira (pereirarhea5@gmail.com), mobile- 8962698567 (Daily 8 am to 8 pm).

Title: Lockdown extension in four MP dists likely after May 3
Article:
Four districts in Madhya Pradesh — Indore, Bhopal, Ujjain and Khargone — might witness extension of lockdown after May 3. After Chief Minister and Health Minister, now Bhopal Collector has hinted in this direction.

Indore, after slight recession in number of positive patients yet again exploded with fresh cases as 84 new cases of coronavirus patients were reported on Friday taking up the tally of total positive patients to 1029 including 55 deaths and 79 patients who have recovered completely.

Besides Indore, the State capital too has ended up a breeding ground of covid19 cases as the city reported 37 new cases by morning on Friday which led to the overall tally reaching 340.

Ujjain is no better as tally of positive cases have reached to 101 here with 11 deaths while Khargone too has been a hotspot of covid19 with 60 cases of infection till now including five deaths.

As the country is inching closer to conclusion of second phase of lockdown by May 3, the State Government is worried about several red zones including these four districts where Covid19 is yet to subside.

Couple of days ago, talking to a news channel, Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan had expressed satisfaction over the fact that half the State was corona-free adding districts like Shivpuri have reined in Covid19 spread.

Chouhan, however, had added that districts including Indore, Bhopal, Ujjain and Khargone could not get relaxation after May 3.

Health and Minister for Home Narottam Mishra during an interaction with the media in Bhopal on Thursday too had hinted that four worst affected districts could see lockdown extended beyond May 3.

Adding that Indore is still the worst affected district in the State, Mishra had feared that the city could see one more surge in positive cases.

Bhopal Collector Tarun Pithode on Friday also claimed that administration was considering extension of lockdown in Bhopal where 10,000 samples were taken, report for 6,000 has been received and remaining is pending.

Title: BJP flays ‘free rice’ through PDS
Article:
Leader of Opposition in the state assembly Dharamlal Kaushik on Friday criticized the state government’s policy of free distribution of ration through PDS shops, terming it as a deception.

The state government is indulging in trading of rice through the panchayat and civic bodies, Kaushik said in a statement.

The government is charging Rs 32.00 per kg of rice from the panchayat while from the urban bodies, it charging Rs 33.13 per kg, he said.

“It means that the state government is selling rice to the local self-governing bodies from the state civil supplies corporation. In the open market, the price of rice is less than what the government is charging,” Kaushik said.

The BJP leader said then it can never be said to be free distribution, when the local self-governing bodies are paying for it.

On issuing of ration cards, he said, earlier the state government said all ration cards have been made. Now, from where did the people not holding ration card have emerged?

“It is double flip-flop on the part of the state government, which it should clarify,” he said.

Kaushik also said that the BJP will constitute an internal three-member committee to probe into the alleged suicide of a young sarpanch in the assembly constituency of the chief minister on Thursday.

Terming the incident on occasion of the ‘National Panchayati Raj Day’ as most unfortunate, he said, “A human being makes all efforts to survive but is forced to take extreme step when left with no other option or his voice goes unheard.

Title: Metro takes up measures to help needy during lockdown
Article:
The Delhi Metro has reached out to personnel who are extending their services to combat the Covid-19 pandemic.

A senior Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC)official said that food distribution drives have been organised at areas such as Nigambodh Ghat, Bangla Sahib and Yamuna Bank and Garhi Mandu to provide support to those in need. More such drives will be organised in the days to come, he said.

As part of its Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives, the DMRC is taking a number of measures during the ongoing lockdown to reach out to the personnel who are extending their services to combat the Covid 19 pandemic.

‘Delhi Metro, in association with one of its vendors Space Tele is also reaching out to the Covid Warriors mainly the Delhi Police personnel deployed at 70 barricades and manning PCRs. DMRC is serving such staff with masks, sanitizers and some food items like biscuits and juices etc, he added.

In areas such as Sonia Vihar and Jagatpuri also, tea and refreshments are being provided to the security personnel who are deputed at the barricade points on the streets, he said.

The official further said that DMRC has also decided to contribute one day’s basic pay (As on April 2020) of its employees towards the PM CARES fund to tackle the Covid 19 pandemic. The DMRC has around 14,500 employees at present.

Title: Uber offers free rides to healthcare workers
Article:
The Delhi Government has joined hands with Uber - Ride hailing platform offering free rides for emergency services. According to Über , it will provide free charge transport for frontline healthcare workers/ Government officials on COVID-19 related duties.

Using microblogging site twitter, Uber tweeted : Proud to pledge free rides worth INR 75 Lakhs to Delhi Govt., for transporting frontline healthcare workers, and other essential services

In their repose, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal also tweeted :Thank you for your support for Delhi’s healthcare workers. It is heartening to see so many organisations pitching in to help fight Corona

It may be recalled Über recently launched its UberMedic service to facilitate the transportation of frontline medical workers in 28 hospital across 14 cities in India. All UberMedic cars being provided to the Delhi government are fitted with a roof-to-floor plastic sheeting.

Title: Elderly couple found dead in house, son suspected
Article:
An elderly couple were found dead inside their house in Durga Vihar area under jurisdiction of Chhawla police station on Friday. Police suspects elderly couple’s son behind the killing.

The deceased have been as Raj Singh (61) and his wife Omwati (58), residents of Durga Vihar area.

According to a senior police official, a police control room (PCR) call was received on Friday at 11.15 am regarding the incident following which an Emergency Response Vehicle (ERV) was dispatched for the spot.

“After reaching the spot, both the victims were found dead on bed inside their room. There were sharp cut marks on the face of both deceased persons,” said the senior police official.

“Both the bodies have been sent for autopsy and the exact cause of death will be ascertained after the post-mortem,” said police official privy to investigation.

“Victims’ son Satish (37) and their daughter-in-law Kavita (35) were also found inside house and they both are suspects,” he said.

“A case has been registered and investigation initiated. Police teams are also questioning the suspects. It seems the case of domestic violence as Satish was unemployed and he had arguments with his parents often, but exact reason will be ascertained after investigation” the police official added.

Title: Follow lockdown during Ramzan: Police to Muslims
Article:
In wake of coronavirus outbreak, the Delhi Police on Friday urged people to follow the lockdown during the holy month of Ramzan.

“Azaan may be carried out in accordance with the NGT guidelines,” police tweeted.

“The pious month of Ramzan starts from 25.04.2020. While observing roza and prayers, we expect everyone to follow lockdown as per the guidelines. Azaan may be carried out in accordance with NGT guidelines. It is requested that Namaz may be performed while staying indoors and have Sehri at home. All must stand united to fight Covid 19 pandemic and follow the guidelines,” the Delhi Police tweeted.

The tweet came after a video went viral on social media where two police personnel were telling persons that the Azaan was not allowed during the lockdown as per Lieutenant Governor’s (L-G) order.
